They said that the valet usually parks the cars on the other side of the bar in the lobby instead of where we dropped it off...Ok no big deal, except we finally see my car and still no valet attendant.Nobody was in sight.I waited around for 10 minutes near my car and other cars and could not find any valet person at all to get my key from.Another thing that shocked me is that they had my Jaguar f type convertible parked on the street with the roof down.There were people near my car taking pictures of it and you can easily open the glove box and the other storage areas from the car with the doors locked because the roof was down. So basically anyone could have took stuff out of my car. No valet person there to watch over it!Eventually found valet attendant when he came back from I am assuming dropping off other customers cars, we got our keys and left.Only to find out that when I got home to PA I noticed that my EZ Pass was missing from my windshield.So now I drove from NYC to PA about 2 hours through several tolls with no ezpass.Someone stole the ez pass from my car ( since it was left open with no valet watching it )I cannot wait to get the bills from NY, NJ turnpike and PA with bills for going through the EZ pass without paying...I had no clue until I got home that it was missing ( noticed when I went through the last toll in pa and the light did not turn green... )All in all we had an amazing trip... I travel frequently and I had an excellent time with my significant other in NYC. However other than enjoying the hotel room we did not really have any fun at all in the hotel which is sad because when I go away and stay in a nice hotel, I normally will just spend most of my time and money in the hotel relaxing...I ended up spending thousands of dollars in other hotels which is a loss for the standard not me... I will not be back...Rocco

The Standard is way above the level of similar hotels. It has all of what you need for a special stay in NYC. Rooms are spacious and very well organized, the view is breathtaking, every single detail has been smartly planned (minibar is spectacular). If you are there just for relaxing and sleeping you'll enjoy the room and the excellent breakfast; if you are there for having fun, the cocktail bar and the terrace are some of the best ever seen.Chapeau

Hotel is super modern and trendy in a great location to a lot of great New York staples. Lobby is cool, rooftop club is super cool, (Just because you stay in hotel does not mean you get into club and they tell you that when you check in) great food and bars in and right next to hotel. So look I am 34 years old and $450 a night hotels are more and more common especially in NYC. If I was staying at this hotel with my wife I would think it was cool and would have less issue with it. Unfortunately I stayed here with my female BFF for her birthday weekend. This hotel has NO ROOMS WITH DOUBLE BEDS... There are no roll aways either. No big deal we are close and we had a king room. The weird part is the shower and bath. There is a huge walk in shower with a bath tub that will fit 4 people right when you enter the room. Guess what it has no door and is open to the room. There are shutters that you can close to the room but there is no door you can close. We made it work but you would think they could install a fogged glass door or something. Also the Shampoo, Body Wash, and Conditioner is mounted to the wall and cannot be moved. (Seriously it requires a tool to refill them.) If you take a bath there is no way to use the bath products as they are on the other side of the massive shower. That was super annoying! Hotel has free Wifi which for a hotel at this price point is rare. All of the people that are in and hanging around the hotel are gorgeous young professionals. You for sure feel cool for staying here. Best part of the hotel was the bed linens. OMG they were the nicest I have ever experienced in my life and I am a bed linen snob.

From the moment you step out of your cab in front of the Standard - you know it is for the chic only. Well, the chic and a bunch of poseurs. It does not feel very welcoming to normal, average, people - like ME! :) There is a snooty vibe all around - I take that back. THE BELL STAFF were not snooty - they were friendly and pleasant. Everyone else (staff and guests) were snooty patooty.And yet. And yet.... I give it FOUR STARS (which is high in my book!). If the attitudes were better and it was not so spray tan fakey - I would give it 10 stars (if TripAdvisor had that option). The room was fantastic!!!! Room 617 - great view, comfy bed, good tv, fine closet, clean... But the SHOWER, the SHOWER is what puts this hotel over the top. AMAZING! Rain forest like feel to the shower head, and you can open the "shutters" over the soaker tub and watch NYC life happen in front of your eyes WHILE SHOWERING. Loved it. Good location - Chelsea Market right around the corner. Not far from metro. Downstairs restaurant food selection at lunch time not that great but the flat bread was good.Downsides (besides the aforementioned snootiness) - DARK. I realize it is hip to be dark and moody, but SO DARK YOU CAN'T SEE IN THE ELEVATOR to push your room button is takin' it a tad bit too far. The whole place is dark (except in my room, where I controlled the lighting :) ). Other negative is price - quite expensive.Go for the view and the shower. Pack your high heels and tightest pants, cuz without them you are going to feel out of place even in the lobby.

Great service, great service! Beautiful room, very simple and clean with outstanding views of he city. Boutique bar areas and outside bar wonderful but small. It is New York after all! I would definitely return. A bit of a scene, but great for people watching. Food is good, service, well, new your waiters do their best! I really enjoyed the place and the staff is very accommodating! I will return!

No doubt, The Standard High Line is the place to be. Quite a few hotels are, these days. However, pleasantly surprised to discover that this busy, trendy hang-out also doubles as a good business hotel. The Standard is two blocks from our NY office, which is a great start, but also made a good effort at looking after hotel guests as well as they do the guys using the bars and restaurants - not always the case. Funky reception with fast, courteous and efficient staff. I was welcomed back, even though my last stay was in '08. Rooms are a tad small but shower and bath are great. Good TV, very well-stocked minibar and amazing views over the Hudson. There are some great restaurants a short distance away, notably the Old Homestead, plus an Apple Store which is open until 2200. Check-out was a dream, considering it was at 0500. I rang down at 0455 to request my bill and to reserve a cab (you cannot book Yellow Cabs), four minutes later my bill was ready, the cab to JFK outside the door and the 'damage' very reasonable. Will go back again, sooner this time!

It's all about location with this hotel. It is situated in the Meatpacking District, a neighbourhood crawling with nice bars and restaurants. If you're looking for a fun weekend to party with your friends this is definitely the place to be. Are you looking for a quiet retreat for your family then you would probably be better of somewhere else.We found the rooms in The Standard to be rather small. We booked a standard king, which had a very small bathroom with a seperate claustrofobic toilet. The room also lacked sufficient storage space for your clothes. The room was clean though.The lack of roomspace did not bother us much, because the food/drink section of the hotel made up for that completely. On the ground floor there is the Grill restaurant with ample indoor & outdoor seating. Breakfast is also served there. The food is simple but really nice. Next door there's a German style Biergarten, where you should definitively try a couple of pints. Showpiece of the hotel is the Top of the Standard, a huge lounge bar on the 18th floor, with stunning views of Manhattan and the Hudson river. One floor up there is a discoteque and a roof terrace (which we did not visit). All of the above highly recommended and with great service. Gets really busy in the weekends.....

This is a great place to stay if you are hip! And I mean really, really hip, not a pretender like me. Rooms are small but with a great view. Bar and dining arrangements are a bit confusing with various entrances, times, dress codes etc. the upstairs bar (the one without the strict dress code) is uber cool hence on a sunny Sunday like today it rather resembled a caged chicken factory for the young uber dudes. Much more preferable are the downstairs restaurants which have great food and drinks, excellent staff and a great view of the passing parade of uberatti. Would I come back? Probably but my wardrobe would require a major renovation first. The free bicycles are a great way to get around and the staff on the front desk are fabulous. I

My husband treated us to a 5 night blow out trip to NYC for my birthday. The Standard was the perfect hotel for us:Fantastic locationAmazing city viewGreat bathtub and showerWonderfully comfortable bedEfficient room serviceWe didn't hear the night club and had no problem checking it out on our last night. The formal bar at the top of the Standard has amazing views.

I booked the Hudson Suite for my final 2 nights during my trip to NYC.... and what a way to end the trip! I highly recommend this suite, its AMAZING! The views are so good that after 2 weeks of running around you don't feel so bad to sleep in that bit longer to enjoy the room while you have it! The staff in general were quite good. Concierge actually were fun and aren't as starchy as some other hotels so thumbs up to them! As a solo I definitely recommend this hotel for other solo travelers. I loved the area, close to lots of night spots and good eats. The only fault I would say is that I had to wait to check in for over an hour as the room had not been cleaned. Although the staff were apologetic I would say that I wasn't really impressed that I had to wait especially since I'd be running around all day. That said, the suite was really worth the wait!

The hotel is in a great location however:1. The hotel caters to casual visitors to the rooftop bars and give little recognition to hotel guests. The congestion at the lifts of a weekend is a nightmare. There is no priority or reserved lift for hotel guests.2. The wifi in rooms drops in and out and to get a constant signal you need to sit in the hallway.3. The TV streaming signal also drops out mid show and often does not return.4. The maids don't replace the soap even when you have to leave a note requesting more.5. Unlike other hotels there are no umbrellas kept at the front desk for guests. If the one in your room is broken, as was ours, there are no others.6. The wardrobe is so small that none of our international bags will fit in it opened or closed.The hotel is very popular but the focus is not on hotel guests. They are clearly making money form people eating and drinking here.

breathtaking views! a great service and cool people.we loved the Standard Grill as well, many thanks to Daryl, the general manager.Only thing is teh room service a bit slow, but food extremely good;the Standard cheeseburger my fav!

Loved my stay at The Standard last month - now THOSE are rooms with a view. Top of The Standard bar is great, but the door girls are rather airheaded and snooty. Full details and pics on my blog: http://hyhoi.com/2014/05/standard-high-line-hotel-new-york/

After just staying at the Standard for one night I can only advise staying far away. We found our room to be acceptable (all be it small with a strange shower layout that for those with mobility issues would present a major issue) as were the dinning options which is good. Now for the problems during the course of a less than 24 hour stay we got stuck on various floors of the hotel for more than fifteen minutes each time with elevator issues. In two cases my wife and I walked down six flights of stairs exiting the building through a service entrance just to leave. Upon notice the hotel seemed unphased at the on going elevator issues and made little attempt to explain or make the issue right. A hotel of this cost must find a way to better communicate and handle there maintenance issues. We won't be back!

Floor to ceiling widows, well laid out rooms and a comfortable stay at a reasonable price for the city. Plenty of places to eat in the area or at the hotel. Room service is pretty quick and the food is good. We will be returning again.

Stayed at this hotel last year - fortunately I was not paying the bill on either ocassion :)Certainly not cheap, but does have the wow factor. Location is perfect within the Meatpacking district and also with direct access to the High Line (my favourite part of NYC - a must see). The rooms are very modern in design, arguably a little small, but well appointed. On this ocassion, if you were not good friends with your room mate, you would be at the end of the trip, as the bed was positioned directly against the wall separating the bathroom. This wall was glass. So you can lie in bed and directly look at the person showering just the other side of that glass :) No time for shyness........... Best feature of this hotel are the huge windows and the views out over the city. Be sure to visit the roof top bar and the view gets even better. The gym also has amazing views, which distract you from the treadmill...

We had another great trip to NYC and our stay at the Standard was exceptional. Paul Cashman once again took great care of us and his hospitality is second to none. Our bellman, Wieser greeted us and made us feel welcome as a returning guest. Our room was on the 11th floor and it was exceptional. The service and food in the grill was excellent.

We had a girls brunch here on a Saturday morning and we were not disappointed. We had a warm greeting and seated immediately. It is a great location and it's a great spot to people watch. The price was fair by new york standards and you have to try the breakfast potatoes.......delicious. Don't remember the name of our server but they all seemed attentive. Would highly recommend. Also, if you get a chance check out the high line, wish I had time to.

The Standard Highline is a fun and funky hotel located in Chelsea and built right up over the Highline park. The hotel is very nicely designed. The rooms are fairly small, but well laid out. The bathrooms are an open European concept with shutters between the bathroom and the main part of the room and feature a large soaker tub. I recommend filling up your tub at night, turning off the lights, opening the shutters and enjoying the fabulous view of the city at night. The bed was super comfortable and I loved the toiletries ( Kiss my Face products). The service was cheerful and friendly. We got some great recommendations from the front desk staff as to the best way to see the Statue of Liberty- loved the Clipper City Sailboat tour! I was also surprised at how quiet the rooms were. A bit of background noise filtering up from the beer garden next door, but I guess this is why they thoughtfully provided earplugs. Had great sleeps overall. Two thumbs up to The Standard. I enjoyed my stay.

I have just gotten home from a week long stay at the standard - please do yourself a favour and skip staying here. The staff will treat you like second class citizens, they will lie to your face regarding what rooms are available and how the night club policy works, you will be able to hear everything people in the next room are doing. Everything. And for 400+ dollars a night you will be offered a shower with hostel-like surroundings and no door. And while the views from the nightclub are great, please don't order the bar menu. For 10 dollars you will get one square inch of wagyu on a stick. Style over substance is predominant here.

This is a great club and a cocktail bar for warm nights to go in NYC but this is the only good reason to stay in the hotel, you get free excess until 9.30 pm , you have a nice gym and the location at the meet packing is ok, the noise at weekends will not bother you if you go to sleep at 3am.The service is bad, and the rooms are old, no swimming pool or design , shampoo is bad.

The hotel is very trendy and the location could not be better. The view from the room was fantastic and the restaurants and bars at the hotel outstanding. We used recommendations from the concierge for breakfast and lunch restaurants in the neighborhood and was amazed with their great knowledge and perfect recommendation to local treasures we would never have found on our own. So listen to their advices, they know their city! The rooms are nice, but small a little dark. It also look a little old and outdated. The staff at the grill and one of the outside bars (not the rooftop) are filled with staff that seems unexperienced and without the ability to manage the logistic. They would benefit enormously with training and improvement in service as they drag down the impression of the hotel quite a lot. With that said, the drinks are very good and the food at the grill are very good. The rooftop bar is fantastic and the waitresses certainly know how to make you feel welcome. The evening we visited the rooftop they had a live jazz band playing which gave the place a "Great Gatsby" feel to it. Over all, a very nice hotel and despite some flaws that drag down the impression I choose not to rob it from a star as the hotel is fresh and fun and I would stay here again.

Started with rooftop drinks and nibbles, overlooking the River. Manhattan was all lit up and the view was amazing. On to dinner at the Grill. Great Cocktails, great food, buzzing atmosphere and great company, what more can you ask for. Was not staying at the Hotel so can't comment on accommodation. Will definitely return on next trip.

I really enjoyed our 5 night stay at this hotel. It was in a more relaxed part of Manhattan and had fantastic views across the river and into the city. You can also take the High Line walk (which begins at The Standard) and walk up Manhattan, which is well worth doing.Our room was spacious and clean. The hotel always smelt amazing (I would like to know what they were pumping through the air con!) and the food was fantastic (particularly breakfast).

We just loved the vibe from the interior design, mod touches, it was an overall great experience.We enjoyed the foie gras on the menu and the open kitchen seating. The boom boom room was pretty sweet with the guys wearing aviator style glasses shaking drinks. Nice touch. High high prices up there. Don't go into shock.

I travelled with my husband. Let me start off by mentioning...the hotel rooms are tiny...even if we booked a Superior King Suite. I mean we had trouble putting our suitcase on the floor and opening it up since there are no real dressers or sufficient room to put away our clothes...so the suitcase stayed on the floor wide open. We even had trouble hanging our bath towels...only 2 hooks. We had friends also staying at the hotel...we tried having a happy hour before dinner...forget having 4 people comfortably seated. The amenities in the room are basic...at this price more than 350$/night; it should be high end, right? At checkout, I told front desk about this when they asked me how were the rooms. Their response was: Well, we are a boutique hotel after all. My answer: I have stayed at many boutique hotels in the past, in NYC and other cities worldwide, and I have never had such a miniscule room for that price. I would expect this in a lesser hotel chain thus less expensive, but not the Standard... I also think that guests should have a priority access to THEIR restaurants and bars...at least some kind of lame waiting list. Nope, nothing for hotel guests. So my suggestion is to enjoy the Standard but you do not have to be a guest at their hotel. Everybody has access to their restaurants and bars...guests or non-guests. They treat everyone the same. So why cough up the 700$ for a 2 night stay. This said, book somewhere else cheaper not too far away. I have to say, we did enjoy their restaurants and bars are great. The staff working at these eateries and bars are superb.

The hotel location is great and the looks fantastic online but the reality of staying in the hotel is disappointing. The hotel is a popular venue so don't expect to get a seat in any of their bars or restaurants without a considerable wait. When we were there the rooftop bar was closed for the entire duration for private functions. Guests don't have priority so you don't feel very welcome.The staff are very friendly and courteous but our experience was that this is a very popular venue so you don't just need to book your room, you need to book everything else too!!Won't be going back, there are so many other lovely hotels around as alternatives.

Stayed at the Standard over the holiday weekend. High energy abounds this hotel. Great area for foodies and west village shopping. The Hotel comes alive after 11 every night and does not dissappoint those youthful guests. Accomdations are tight, but on trend with European and modern flair. Views are amazing....will stay again without hesitation.

I stayed for four nights over a long weekend. If you are seeking a hip boutique hotel in the heart of the city - this is a great option. In Chelsea, it is walking distance from TriBeCa, SoHo, NoLita, and all the other great parts of the city. The incorporation of High Line is unique. The room was spacious by NYC standards - equipped with little touches (complimentary umbrella, iron, docking station, etc.). The rooftop bar boasts a great view - particularly at sunset. However, the scene is exactly what you'd expect for a hipster bar in the meatpacking district.Unfortunately, the hotel misses the mark for an excellent rating. Despite multiple requests, the chambermaid did not change my broken table top ironing board. And while the staff at the reception were very friendly and helpful, the maintenance guy who came to fix the dead battery in the phone was not the most polite. The room decor was stylish but the construction was a little sloppy (e.g., uneven tiles at the bathroom entrance). While there is a large bath, the shower is a European style that floods the bathroom - not my first choice in bathroom design. Again, it is a very good hotel and I would consider staying there again but it is not in the same league as some other options in a city with a plethora of boutique hotels.

The hotel is located in the heart of meat-packing, so if your looking for bars and clubs, they are right on the doorstep. Cabs stop right on the doorstep And I didn't have any problem in this department whilst I was there.The rooms were nothing to write home about, but generally adequate. They are extremely small, which whilst not uncommon for NY, are Certainly far smaller than others in that price range. There is no separate bathroom, and instead it is at one end of the bedroom with a glass screen (pretty cheap trick and hope you aren't expecting privacy?!). No complimentary water or anything is provided and the general feel is more one of a cheap motel in the room.All of this is tolerable albeit in no way particularly impressive for the price, however the one thing that really bothered me was the facilities. The roof bar and club, are run by some of the most obnoxious snooty and arrogant characters I've had the misfortune of meeting. So exclusive are they trying to be that despite paying 500 dollars or so to stay there, you're not actually allowed to visit your own rooftop bar after a certain time without begging and bartering with the idiot on the door to let you in!! On discussing this with the receptionist I was flippantly told I ought to try and get on the DJs invite list?! Sorry...but that isn't the way it works in a quality hotel! The restaurant is also a high quality restaurant, but absolutely no preference/allowance is given to those staying there. In short, you end up In a Situation where you can't eat at the hotel restaurant and you can't drink at the hotel bar!! And all of this whilst your paying hundreds of dollars to stay there. The management really need to work out what their preference is here, you can't expect people to spend those bucks and not at the very least ensure they can use the hotel restaurants and bars at will.I am returning to NY in a couple of weeks, but I won't be back to the Standard. I'll probably go back to the Langham Place, where you aren't made to feel like a pleb who has to beg for entry just because you would like a drink on the roof.

My wife & I stayed here the night of our wedding. The room was glamorous with amazing views of The Hudson & lower Manhattan. The patio at the front of the hotel was also open late for drinks, which provided a great outdoor place to have a nightcap with some of our guests. Slept like a rock after all the wedding festivities left us just needing a good night's rest.

A real cool hotel in a very cool area of Manhattan. The view over High Line and the Hudson River is perfect to wake up to. The restaurant has very good breakfast, but at a rather scary price compared to going out eating elsewhere. The room we had, which was a Deluxe room, was the smallest room we ever stayed in in the US. The bed was good, even if it covered 90% of the floor. The shower was more cool than functional, but all in all it was a nice stay. We were never able to get to the presumably cool bar at the top floors, since it was always queues outside and the inside elevator was blocked at evenings.

This is supposed to be a boutique hotel! The rooms are anything but that. They are average rooms with basic toiletries. The rooms are just basic! The front desk staff is not overly accomodating or friendly. The restaurants, lounges, bar, etc. are GREAT. The Boom Boom room close at 10:30 PM for an exclusive guest list of the property's owner is what we were told. And the rooftop bar has a very long line to get in. Guests of the hotel have no priority to these two venues or any of the other services in the hotel. The Valet staff is great and are very accomodating and professional. This is a very trendy hotel in a great location that will soon fade away. Sav your money and stay somewhere else.

The room and the lobby area are absolutely stunning. The view from our room on the 14th floor made my jaw drop. My husband and I didn't think the room was too small, plenty of room to move about and appreciate the view from different angles. The bathtub was the best bathtub ever, big enough for two people side-by-side. We only stayed for a few nights, so didn't interact with the staff too much, but they seemed nice enough. The location is great, the High Line is a must-do in New York and there are heaps of great places to eat and shop in nearby Chelsea & Greenwich Village. This place is worth the money if only for the view; the bath, the decor and the location were huge bonuses!

We stayed for 3 nights and loved it. We got a free upgrade to a Hudson room after we inquired about it prior to arrival but declined due to the price.The rooms are small but what nyc hotel isn't. It was big enough given you shouldn't be in your room that much anyway because there is s much to do in and around the hotel. Bingo on Monday night downstairs was going crazy at midnight when we were there. Not sure what some reviewers are saying about using earplugs. We never heard anything. Would definitely go back.

What to say that you have not read before! This place has it all! The rooms design is very sleek, rooms have amazing views, the bedding was perfect not to soft nor too hard. Size is small but then again compared to New York it is in line with the standards.Their restaurants and bars are great, awesome vibe! Loved the Standard grill (amazing cheese cakes) and if you can get in, the boom boom room is awesome!I loved it but can understand that this hotel is not for all...let's put it this way, if you are their to have a beauty sleep, it is not for you!

We spent 4 nights at The Standard Hotel High line and really enjoyed the experience as a couple in our early 40s. The hotel has a great location in the Meatpacking District. Loads of good restaurants and bars around. The rooms are small and bathrooms without doors but it works out if you stay as a couple. We had both breakfast and dinner at the Standard Grill which was good but pricey. They are better options around but there is a great atmosphere and buzz all over the hotel. Overall a good hotel in a great location and so much better than staying Midtown. We will be back.

When we checked in the friendly lady said she would send bottle complementary champagne but it never arrived. Rooms are small but expected that. Need more pillow options. Didn't like the exposed shower. Nice hotel though. Busy on weekends upstairs and down. Downstairs bar make great cocktails

The Standard Highline is a truly cool hotel over top the Highline. Our room had an excellent view and the Meatpacking District is a great area of Manhattan. We had no trouble utilizing the hotel's valet parking service which was very convenient and reasonable for NYC. Our room was clean, super comfortable and reminded us of the ergonomic rooms we're familiar with seeing in Europe. The Biergarten on the ground floor is reminiscent of being in Munich but not quite. It's expensive but it is Manhattan and we did enjoy the atmosphere, pretzels and beer. The Sunday afternoon crowd was quite young (mostly 20 something), energetic, and fun. We shared an outstanding dinner at The Spice Market just a block away. Our weather was less than cooperative so we enjoyed some time at the Chelsea Market checking out the wide array of shops. Some time on the Highline is a must weather permitting. Look for coupons or promo codes for a possible discount at The Standard. I saved $100 with the promo code I found. I would recommend the hotel to friends visiting NYC.

Stayed 6 nights in april 2014 on a business trip. Had a 17th floor room facing uptown. Beautiful unobstructed views of the city. Room is intelligently designed and everything "seems in the right place". Because of the various bars/restaurants in the complex, the lobby can be a bit tough to negociate at night, but not a big deal. Staff is pleasant. Wifi not free and it should have been.

This hotel has the best location, fantastic restaurant, friendly staff, comfortable bed, so why wouldn't I go back? The corner suite we booked was not cheap , so when we were shown to our room I couldn't believe how small it was, even for New York standards. So small , one side of the bed was jammed against the window and one had to jump over the end of the bed just to get out. The cupboard was just a hole in the wall with a curtain! We had trouble storing our three suitcases and were constantly in turmoil getting clothes out etc. it was a long five days.Soooo disappointed

We have just got back from 4 nights staying at The Standard. We have been to New York loads of times, but as this trip was our honeymoon, we wanted somewhere pretty special. We weren't disappointed!We had room 1223 with amazing views of the river, Liberty and The Freedom Tower. We slept with one set of curtains open, so we didn't miss the view from the moment we woke up.The room was a brilliant size, open plan. The bath in the middle of the room felt very decadent while we sipped bubbly, soaking, taking in NY around us.The bed gave us the best nights of sleep we've ever had. The linen is very soft and luxurious. The bed; massive! The staff are really friendly & helpful. They booked dinner reservations for us. Booked taxis. Gave us free coffee! Le Bain have us a truly epic Saturday night. We couldn't quite believe we were there. The view, music and atmosphere have given us memories and pictures to treasure. The hotel has got it spot on. We really did 'Stay Cool' in NYC. And we won't stay anywhere else from now on. The Standard has got it all!

Stayed here last night, easy check in, friendly staff, panoramic views from the room on the 19th floor, and the room was spacious with plenty of room. The bed was extremely comfortable and the whole setup was great. I usually stay in the W in Union Square but will be back at the Standard on my next trip. Good location with plenty of nearby options for places to head out in the city.

Have stayed here on numerous occasions all for short periods and each time I come back I feel at home and in the real NYC. Although the rooms are quite small ( all rooms in NYC are small), the views are extraordinary and makes the space seem much larger. At The standard you are in the thick of things with regards to nightlife/ fashion / art etc. This is a very happening are close to great shopping/ dining / nightlife and activelifestyles. The highline and the west side are great areas to go jogging /walking and the latter has a bike/inline path. The staff here are friendly and well informed. I look forward to my next stay here

Great views and location but that's about it. Got woken up three nights in a row living on the 16th floor due to poor sound proof of the walls and windows. Taxi cab disputes translate to long and sustaining horns that can be heard all the way up in here. Being two rooms away from the elevator also means that ever single up and down operation can be monitor by your ear. Lots of randos trying to play around with gym equipments and the receptionists at the front desk have uniforms that tried to show way too much creating a quite low class feeling. Come here to dine or party but 0/10 would recommend staying here.

My boyfriend and I spent a long weekend in NYC back in March, spending two nights at the Palace in Midtown (a longtime fave of mine) and two nights at the Standard High Line (my first time) -- very different hotels obviously, but the thing that they both got pitch-perfect was SERVICE and STAFF.From the super adorable, super funny, super welcoming bell guys Scott and Tim to the gorgeous and efficient Caitlin at the front desk, from the moment we arrived at the Standard High Line, any sadness we'd felt about leaving the old school Midtown magnificence that is the Palace was quickly replaced by excitement, fun and happiness at/with our new digs.Highlights:- Service! Again, I distinctly remember Scott and Caitlin as being some of the best hotel staffers I've ever encountered (and I stay in schamancy hotels relatively frequently, and don't typically find myself so good with remembering anyone's name -- these two stood out). Usually I find the staff at hotels like the Standard are a little off-putting and cold, but Scott and Caitlin couldn't have been warmer, friendlier or more helpful. A+++ to whoever is doing the hiring at the High Line.- Food! We ate at the Standard Grill twice (brunch and dinner), and both meals were impeccable. The service at the Grill wasn't nearly as good as it was otherwise in the hotel, but still perfectly fine and the food totally stood out. And the characters who frequent the Grill on a Sunday night are something to behold! Worth the $$$ for people-watching alone.- The Boom Boom Room! While this was my first time actually staying at the Standard High Line, I've been to the Boom Boom Room on more than a few occasions before with friends who live in NYC, and I maintain that it is the most beautiful bar I have ever been in, or likely will ever be in. An exceptional room with the kinds of views that dreams are made of. The cocktails aren't half-bad, either.- Bathtub! With a glass of champagne and fresh pears from room service + a book + my boyfriend, I fear I shant say more, but OMGGGG. The bathtub/shower sitch alone makes the Superior King room at the Standard worth every penny.Lowlights:- Compared with Midtown, the rooms are pretty small (but then again, so is everything/everywhere in NYC). The designers made really really good use of the space, that said, so you don't feel caged in like you do some other places (ahem, the W....)- None. I didn't want to leave and am already planning my next stay in June.

My husband and I stayed for two nights as part of my 56th birthday celebration. We chose the location because of the Highline and it's location in general. Other than our plans to see a show on Saturday, we had no plans except to walk on the Highline and along the Hudson River park. These are two amazing resources in NYC. We liked our room on the 6th floor overlooking the Highline. The bed was perfectly comfortable. The mini bar was so extensive that it took up any space that would / should otherwise have been available for folded clothing. There was very little space anywhere for folded clothing in fact. That was our only complaint about the room. We loved all of the different bars and restaurants in the hotel. That's where the 'something for everybody' comes in. There are bars and restaurants in doors, outdoors, upstairs and downstairs. We felt comfortable among the young, funky crowd which we found to be very much a European group. The breakfast food in the standard Grill was among the best we've ever had. We went back on the second morning because it was so good. We would highly recommend this hotel and we do plan to bring our young adult children with us next time!

We just left the Standard Highline and it was one of the best hotels I've ever stayed in. Perfect decor, great restaurants, outdoor patio was great for drinks, and the rooms are so cool. We had a corner king room with a huge bathtub and perfect view of the Empire State Building flashing it's lights all night to watch from the bed. The only glitch was the snooty restaurant at the top floor. We made reservations for Sunday brunch and they informed us that it was formal cocktail attire - for brunch! We bailed but with so many restaurants in the neighborhood, never regretted it. Overall though, a stellar hotel that I will return to again and again!

OK I'll agree to one thing right away: the rooms have great views and I selected the Standard High Line for that reason. I love the building and the area so The Standard High Line was a natural choice.My room was on the 13th floor (no superstition) and faced downtown. View was OK (Whitney Museum of American Art in progress). The room is fairly spacious for NYC. Loved the little nook with the bench and table.My disappointment is with the little attention you are given. I stayed two nights. Complimentary water was offered only on the first night. Turn down service was offered only on the first night as well... I'm used to little attentions (like next day's weather, a chocolate etc.) with turn down - especially at this price range (even in NYC). Here nothing.Oh yeah, and on the 13th floor you can hear the music from the roof-top club throughout the night. Nice.I wouldn't recommend the Standard High Line, except if you get a good deal.

Stayed at the Standard for 3 nights. The hotel, restaurant and bars were great. Rooms were modern with floor to ceiling windows. Ours had a great view of the Empire State building. My only complaint was that it was a bit noisy. We could hear the noise from the street and the rooftop bar. I would not use this as an excuse not to go back. Beds were very comfortable and the Bathrooms were really cool. There were so many positives on our visit that outweigh the noise factor. The restaurant was very good too. Food and service for dinner were great. Service for breakfast was so so. But we were not in a hurry so it was fine. I would definitely go back to the Standard. The location and the experience were great.

We booked four nights at the hotel but we stayed on for another four nights due a medical emergency. The staff was very kind and helpful with the arrangements. The rooms very nicely furnished and the views fabulous.

Stayed a weekend in spring 2013. High floor, 2 from the top, no issues with noise from the club above. Rooms have incredible views and are very interesting, to the say the least. Yes the rooms are tiny but they are very modern in style, with full floor to ceiling windows and see-through window into the shower. Highline is right there, so its great access to walking on a nice day. There are tons of shops and restaurants in the immediate vicinity too. The general area has a lot to offer in the same regard. Maybe the best location in the city to be a homebase for a visit.The hotel staff is very good and valet/check-in/etc was a breeze. The drinks and food at the hotel establishments are very good. Recommend the hotel restaurant for breakfast/brunch and the outdoor patio for drinks. The top-floor bar makes great, if not super expensive drinks, but good vibe and awesome views. It is worth the visit.The rooftop club was not open during our stay. The beer garden gets packed so get there early to avoid a line. Note that you get no special consideration at any hotel clubs, bars, or restaurants for being a hotel guest. Props to the hotel staff all around as I bet they deal with a lot of crap on the weekends, most of the people on the property aren't hotel guests but just there to party.

I stayed here for 10 days and loved it! The staff is incredibly helpful, the vibe is very cool. The rooms are small, but very well designed. The floor to ceiling windows allow for an amazing view of the city. The food is great (breakfast french toast is amazing) and there are a number of restaurants within walking distance, including upscale, diners, burger joints, Thai food and Chelsea Market. The location is fantastic. It is a great place to sit on the patio and people watch as there were a number of fashion shoots going on (and a few celebrity sitings) while I was there. I will definitely recommend this hotel!

Everything about this hotel is amazing. The staff - particularly the concierge staff are fantastic and very helpful. Location is fantastic. The beer hall area is definitely a bit of fun. Hate the token system, but I guess can put up with that.

One of the best places to stay in NYC.The location is great, next to the high line park, amazing view from its roof top, rooms are very clean, cozy and staff will provide you a nice time in there!The view from rooms is also amazing, and i´d recomend it for a a romantic trip!

I stayed here with some friends for a buddy's bachelor party. While some of the guys bunked together, I had my own room, which I'm very thankful for in retrospect. First off, the location and restaurants in the hotel are great - no complaints there. The bar at the top is nice too, albeit a bit pricey. The rooms on the other hand are very average. While nicely decorated, my queen superior room was tiny and had a "peekaboo" shower (which means someone can just sit there and watch you shower through a glass wall) - so if I was sharing, it would have made for some interesting moments. I saw several rooms and they were all pretty much the same (some were even "larger" or had king beds) - very limited space, though nicely decorated.Overall, good for me for a weekend trip in a room by myself, bad if you have someone else or want some space.

Every year I spend 1 or 2 weeks in NYC for business and for vacations. For the first time I was guest in The Standard. An excellent hotel for the location and for the dimensions of the room. During the week end the hotel is a masse because there is a terrible traffic to the 18th floor in a wonderfulll bar. Here there aren't a dress code but some clerks that without roules but by sentiment decide if you are or not accetable in the 18th floor. On friday I was with my guests ( for business !) , repulsed because I had white laces in black shoes, but at the same time was accept 2 couples where the boys were drunk !!!! No comment !

On previous trips to NY, I have always stayed around time square, but always ended up at most times eating and drinking down in the meat packers. That will now change, as this hotel in all it's uniquness is so well positioned in the lower meat packers district, close to all bars, restaurants, clubs and transport. It's a great locations with highlights as follows -The roof top bar was sensational and great vibe + viewBeer garden was amazing and we had some great times with good mixed crowdsAll three restaurants are special in their own way and have great cuisineThe rooms are very trendy and have amazing views. Showers and toilets were average though...Trivia nights were so much fun!I will definately be back next year!

I made reservations in advance to stay at this hotel for my co-worker and I. We decided we could share a king bed and save a little $$... I checked in around 10pm- And then I immediately checked out ten minutes later. I have stayed at this hotel in the past and the room that they gave me was the last room they had available. It was teeny tiny (and I know that hotel rooms in NYC are smaller than usual) but this was a joke. The bed was up against the shower and on the floor. There was no way two people could share the bed without crawling on each other. The closet and bathroom were awful. It looked as thought they had forgotten to clean several areas of the room. I called to the front desk and they had no other rooms to move me into. I checked out immediately and went across the street where I payed 1/2 the price- and the room was twice as big and much cleaner and nicer! The front desk manager at The Standard High Line said they were not going to charge me for the evening because I didn't stay in the room and because they could not offer me another room. They apologized for the room being dirty and unacceptable. But I got charged over $528 for the night on my card. I called and left voicemails for the manager but never received a phone call back. It is such a shame. I have stayed at the STDHL before, and can say that now I will not be coming back again. I wish their customer service was better and that they made this right.

Very stylish hotel with fantastic views and stunning interior design. Great location for those that want the buzz of being close to the Chelsea Market, Meat Packing district etc. The roof top bar has nightly jazz and is very popular. Al fresco bar at ground floor level too. Staff were very friendly helpful and a very nice touch is the complimentary bikes which are available for hotel guests. With the Hudson River bike trail so close this is a very useful option for those wishing to explore Lower Manhattan or even heading across to Greenwich, Soho or the East Village. Superb hotel. Would love to return to one day!

One if the very few places in NY I saw such big rooms with huge windows with the view to the river, but not the neighbor building windows :))) super dance interior, friendly people. Close to the most posh and hipster places of ny, situated right in the center of meatpacking area.

This hotel is well located if you want to spend your time in the lower side of NYC. Easy access to Chelsea Market, Soho and other great locations. The hotel is very active, great ambience, good food and a nice Beer-garden.

The Standard provides amazing atmosphere for a romantic stay. Me and my partner were able to enjoy each other in the utmost comfort of a standard double room with floor to ceiling windows and fantastic views of Manhattan and the High Line. The perfect weekend getaway without leaving the city!PS: the bed was unbelievable!

The room was clean and the bed was really really nice, we slept very well! There is no door to the bathroom, and just a glass wall to the bath tub (a small door to the toilet), so don't choose this hotel unless travelling with someone very close to you.The resturant "The Standard Grill" was packed every evening, but we had breakfast there once which was very nice with generous portions and not too expensive.Upon check in it took a really long time for the room to get ready, we had to wait or stroll around the neighbourhood for about two hours and kept checking in at the reception to ask if it was ready, getting different time estimates each time. This was a bit irritating. They also tried to solve this by downgrading (!) us to a room with a queen size bed. I think that they should have upgraded us if anything.Overall, a very good hotel with some minor annoyances.

The Highlights....Great location and fantastic views - if you choose the right 'room with a view' on offer! The Boom Boom Room is a great cocktail bar on the 18th floor, good vibe, good people watching and great jazz! The side bar at reception level is a cool hang out space until the early am; good for late night food and drink owls! The Lowlights....tiny room size, even by New York standards! We stayed in a corner Hudson view, amazing view not to mention the spectacular sunsets but don't bring the cat! Strange change to the lift system at night for residents, access to the Boom Boom Room after 10pm is back out on the street, and likewise for the return! The Standard Grill...the name says it all, don't go for the service or expecting amazing cuisine. Tried it twice and despite having more staff on the floor than diners, they still cannot get it right. Highlight of this hotel is the High Line position and view.

The rooms are small, but design choices make them feel much larger. What did you expect in New York? Beds are amazingly comfortable, and make sure to get a room with a tub... oh, the tubs.Spend some time outside the hotel just people watching. A very diverse and interesting crowd stays at the standard. Very international. The hotel is in the heart of the meatpacking district, which is now a major international fashion spot. High end clothing stores, supermodel photo shoots. It's all here.Amazingly friendly staff. Just be a human being, and all doors here open. A special thanks to Michael, Justin, and Bridgette at the lounge bar, and Mike the Hop for his wisdom and advice. If for nothing else, I'll always enjoy my stays here because of the wonderful people who work here.

I really enjoyed my stay here, mostly because of the novelty of waking up and being able to see the Empire State Building from my room and shower!Lovely room. Huge bed. Everything I needed was there (including shower gel). Had a really nice porter who was really helpful as well.I had breakfast two mornings in the Standard Grill which is supposed to be one of the best places there, and I wasn't impressed. The staff were kind of rude and not very clear. (I went in and stood waiting for a while, before someone told me I should go and stand on the other side of the room...which makes no sense if you have people from the hotel in there to have breakfast) The food wasn't good.I had a three course meal there for dinner one night as well and I wasn't massively impressed by that either. I found it quite overrated.However, the room was *amazing* with a fantastic view and I really enjoyed my stay.A note for people considering staying: you can see through the shower, so make sure you stay with someone you don't feel uncomfortable being naked around! I was on my own so it was fine - could have showered while looking at the Empire State!

We came with our 14 month son for Xmas, before coming we read many reviews so believe it match our expectations, as rburn says: "Hip and modern located in Meat Packing District", perhaps the rooms are a bit tight for a baby cot, but the sunset/sunrise with those magnificent views makes it worth, make sure you get a room facing the Hudson River.Restaurant downstairs is good and open till late, and gets busy with locals. The only but we can say is that we where not allowed to have a drink on upstair bar (child was obvious minus 21), not even to go in to have a look! Might understand as targets the trendy NYC locals, be aware of dressing code, no fancy sport shoes or jeans allowed as well. The Lift was a surprise, animations coming out from a Dali dream?. Will come back!

The Standard is a hip design hotel. Its always busy because of the restaurants and bar in the premises. We found the rooms to be quite small and had to change hotels even though we had a booked a 6 night stay. Having said that, the staff was more than ok to cancel our reservation without a penalty fee. I would only suggest you visit the Grill and the bar at the top for drinks with a nice view, but avoid staying there if you are looking for a hotel with the proper amenities and service. Unfortunately nobody offered to help us with our luggage (4 people with 4 big suitcases). There is absolutely no room to place your clothes in the room. The shower is always visible from the rest of the room as there is only one glass divider. At the 4th floor, our room was very noisy, since the street is always busy and traffic is heavy during the night.

This hotel is nicely located in Meat Packing District, close to many upscale shops and very nice restaurants and bars. Also close to Chelsea Market. The rooms (I had a deluxe room on the 12th floor with great views over the Hudson and High Line) was very nicely decorated, but I missed a wardrobe, so all clothes had to stay in the suitcases. The bed is great but the shower is really poor. No pressure on the water. The bars are very nice, the view and decor in the BoomBoom room great, the staff not all that great, the ladies at the entrance of the BoomBoom room were pretty arrogant, really not professionals. Breakfast at the Grill very nice, good selection, also again very nice decor. Staff different level of quality.

We stayed here twice, the 1st one (Dec 13) we stayed in the standard room but wow the view is amazing! The location is great too, hotel is modern trendy, staff are super helpful. The lift is amazing, it's completely dark, black with surreal video clip on both side. The 2nd time (Jan 14) we chose to stay in this hotel again and get a better room. Nice surprise, they upgraded us to the corner room with a free standing bath over looking the Hudson. The view is amazing, on the left side we can see The Liberty, straight opposite the bed is the Hudson and on the right side is the Empire State Building. We love it to bits! What's better is our flight to London is cancelled due to snowstorm and our airline agreed to pay our extended stay in this amazing hotel room. We stayed extra 4 nights. We will definitely stay at this hotel again whenever we are going to New York in the future.

What an amazing hotel. Great location. Best New York experience. We stayed here in December over the New Years Eve period and it did not disappoint. We were on about the 14th floor with views of the Empire State. It was just amazing. Rooms are very cool, clean, staff were great. Close to great boutiques, restaurants and the Chelsea Market. Highly recommend staying here!

For the third year in a row, my husband and I "escaped" the kids and headed into the city for a little R&R. Never a disappointment, we returned to The Standard High Line for another awesome weekend! Everything was excellent, from room check-in, to room service, to reservations…all were effortless and a pleasure! Front office director Paul Kashman was on top of everything…even hooking us up with the hotel's bikes for a rare"warm spell" in the midst of a miserably cold winter! Can't wait to return!

We have stayed here several times. Love the location. Love the restaurant. The rooms are looking pretty worn out. There are no drawers and the closet is about 8 inches wide. Ragged carpet, torn headboard, ratty towels. The higher floors are great because the view is incredible - but closer to the night club - which is LOUD until late into the night.

Staying there frequently, but was very disappointed considering the price- hotel becoming shabby! Curtains were dirty and there was a general worn look, Restaurant was still excellent. There was no luggage rack and closet was tiny.

The Standard High Line is a great hotel with great service. I have stayed at several Standard hotels over the years and was especially pleased with the service at this hotel. Located on the west side, with many lovely bars, cafes and restaurants in the area. We were fortunate to be upgraded to a room with great views of the Hudson River.

We thought we'd try a different area of NYC, for our weekend break. The hotel itself is beautifully trendy. As we were there in December, they have an ice skating rink outside, a German style Bier Garden next door, and an amazing lounge and club upstairs. The lounge and club are very exclusive, so even as hotel guests we were unable to enter, as there was a private party going on. Check in was quite manic, a very busy area, and after a long haul flight not very welcoming, however during the course of the weekend we found the reception staff very helpful. A modern room with a great view over the Hudson, rain-style shower-head and all glass walls that gave a view of the bedroom, and the river beyond. Only problem the walls were thin. We ate at the grill room twice, the food and service was great, good wine selection, great steaks! Beautiful hotel, right on the Highline, we enjoyed walking there, despite the freezing cold. Close to Chelsea market, which was a delight for foodies like us. In fact the area had some great restaurants, and shops, and was convenient to access other NY neighbourhoods, we would definitely go back to this hotel and area.

We stayed at this hotel right after New Years and it was great! The floor to ceiling windows and the view of the river was excellent. The tip I have is that to go to the club upstairs you have to exit the hotel and walk around the side to enter the club and make sure you stay on floors 10-14 otherwise you will hear the music from the club.

Everyone told me I had to stay at the Standard Highline, so I stayed. The hotel itself is beautifully modern and très chic. For winter they have an ice skating rink outside, a German style Bier Garden (think mini-hofbrauhaus) next door, and an incredible lounge and club upstairs. These are all things I've experienced as a non-hotel guest.As a hotel guest you get no real perks to any of the above (except free vouchers to the ice skating rink if you ask). The lounge and club are still very exclusive and I wouldn't be surprised if hotel guests found themselves unable to enter.The room itself was straight out of the 1930s - 40s. A sleek old-world modern room that reminded me of the era of Raymond Loewy. The shower had a rain-style shower-head and all glass walls that gave a view of the bedroom. The room itself had fixed "window-walls" that gave a beautiful view of the city. All-in-all the modern style of the hotel and the "old world modern" style of the rooms didn't match.When I went to use the bathroom in my room the light died immediately. To change the bulb required a screwdriver and I had checked in late. I was also woken up by the room below me, since the bed is next to the windows, which sound travels through quite well. This is most likely why the room came with earplugs. All in all - Beautiful hotel and the all glass bathroom was an experience. I'll be back for the lounge, but at that price-point I'd most likely stay at a different location. My recommendation: If you're looking to party and don't care about money than I'd highly recommend this hotel, but stay in one of the highest tier rooms. Also make sure to have non-sneaker dress shoes and pants other than jeans if you hope to enter the lounge.

It was Valentine's Day, we were flying out from the west coast and were met head on by the east coast's polar vortex. We had flight delays, cancellations, and crazy weather. Despite everything that stood in our way, all stress and worry was shed the second we stepped into the Standard Hotel. Special mention must be made to Tim Markman - after years of travelling the world, I have never met such a fine concierge. The bellman were also deserving of mention - we want to thank Weezer for his kind smile and exceptional service. My girlfriend and I hope to see you all again soon!

Came to The Standard High Line for a late valentines day/Presidents' Day "staycation" and could not have been more pleased. Upon arrival we learned that we had been given an about magic upgrade to the next room category, which included a deep soaking tub for two (perfect for the romance factor for valentines day). The room was a beautiful south facing room (overlooking the Hudson and downtown manhattan). We had a small issue wight the television but a quick call to the front desk and the tv was up and running within 5 minutes. The lighting and decor are modern and sleek and offered the perfect backdrop to the floor to ceiling windows' view. Room service in the morning came a bit cold, however, the pancakes and French toast were delicious. All-in-all a great stay.

Just loved The Standard during my recent visit to New York. Great service provided by frendly staff & innovative installations.The top roof bar is amazing and provide great views of Manhatan and New Jersey as well.

Stunning view! Downtown to the statue of liberty and Hudson river & on the other side, uptown towards the Empire State Building…just amazing. All the facilities and service were great. Location is perfect, near the meatpacking district and lots of restaurants in the area. Modern design & cool atmosphere. The Grill restaurant at the hotel is a great choice, cosy & charming with delicious menu. We had a great stay!

I stayed at the Standard for 2 weeks in Feb 2014, in order to prepare fashion week (I work in fashion). I appreciated the place because it is central, invigorating and dynanic.The big difference with other trendy hotels is the staff: they are very welcoming and efficient. There is one name in particular I remember, Alex Gross, who kindly helped me on several occasions at the front desk and guests service. Tell her hi for me if you are staying in this hotel any time soon!

This past weekend, my wife & I celebrated our anniversary by stay-cationing at the Standard Hotel in the Meatpacking District. The weather may have been single digits, but combined with massages & dinner, I’m very happy with our decision to stay local as we reminisced about our nice & warm, beach wedding. Ahh, nostalgia… Thinking back to our experience, a few things stand out. First, our corner room (#823) had floor to ceiling windows on 3 sides. While laying in bed, it literally felt like we were floating as we took in the view of TriBeCa, New Jersey & Midtown. I have never been in a hotel room that evoked similar feelings. The huge bathtub (for 2) is also positioned so that you can chill out and enjoy the tri-angle views. It really provided an enjoyable segue to our late dinner at Spice Market (1 block away). The standalone shower with glass walls definitely added to the mood as well, this room was clearly designed with happy couples in mind. Second, the front desk staff at The Standard seem to be trained exceptionally well. It’s common in many hotels for the staff to be polite, it’s a given. However, the staff at The Standard are conscious that their clientele are upscale and accustomed to white glove treatment. From the receptionist, to the bellhop, to the doorman and concierge, everyone makes it a point to continuously let guests know that they are there to serve them, in any way. It’s a very warm feeling. It’s kind of like when you are at home and hosting one of your parent’s boss for dinner. Obviously mom’s boss can take the fine china home if she likes it that much. I spoke with the manager, Paul Kashman, and conveyed our elation with the chic, upscale ambience. It’s evident that Paul has been doing this for many years. Lastly, we went to the Soho House for massages at Cowshed Spa. We are not members at Soho House, but because we were staying at The Standard, we were able to obtain access. I’m not sure if access to Soho House is possible otherwise, but checking out the private club was a nice touch. Although we live in Manhattan, the last few days have consisted of me thinking (a few times) of occasions for which we can have another stay-cation at The Standard. I look forward to it.

This hotel is certainly not for everyone; but I really liked it. It is a boutique hotel; ultra modern. Appears to be a hotel for the beautiful and cool. A very trendy place with very, very small rooms (as most are in NYC). The place is easy to find; just look for the upside-down logo (by design of course). Location is excellent (meat packing district) and a walk around is a must. There is a cool beer garden next door. This is a cool and pricey hotel with a few quirks... Not exactly sure how to describe it, but the bed mattresses set directly on the floor; no frame. So it's a little low for me getting up in AM but I got used to it. The patio bat outside is cool; service average to below average. Be prepared for the smallest bathroom (separate toilet area) that you have ever seen or could ever imagine. The elevators to the rooms are coolest elevators I have ever been in; hard to describe the cool visual effects.

Like every year since this great hotel opened it's doors my wife and I still enjoy to stay at the Standard (this time 5 nights). The check-in is always fast and friendly. The staff in general (and especially the concierges Tim & Kevin) are charming, friendly and very professional.We enjoyed a Standard King room on a higher floor with views towards the Empire State building. The bed is very comfortable, we like the little table and chair and the location in the meatpacking is just perfect. There are many lovely cafes and restaurant nearby (West Village). We also enjoy very much a lovely cocktail before sunset in the bar on top of the Standard. This bar as well as the adjoing night Club Le Bain are not run by the Standard hotel management, so it's understandable that hotel guests are not automatically admitted. I read a lot of negative comments about angry hotel guests punishing the rating of the Standard (which I think is not fair) because of door policy of the Boom Boom Room/Le Bain licensees.

I love the room and the little notice to let you know people can watch you from outside and for your privacy make sure your blinds/ curtains are closed.Love all bar they have all have great service and are amazing.

Had a 2 night stay on a business trip with high expectations of this hotel.The whole experience very poor especially for the rate we paid. Yes the rooms have great views over the Hudson but for me that's were it ends. No control on aircon in the room - it was far too hot. Luxurious deep bath tub but the water wasn't hot enough even if it could have stayed in the tub - the plug was broken! Ah well a walk in shower no problem here the water was hot enough to give 3rd degree burns!!An early evening drink with colleagues on the 18th floor - staff very abrupt and rude insisting you deposit your coat in the cloak room. Bar itself OK - have been in better in the district - but leave at your peril!! If you the leave the bar and return after 10.00pm you are told in no uncertain terms You cannot come in! Despite being guests the bar turns into a private members club and guests are not welcome. Even with the intervention of the reception management you are still not welcome. The hotel have made a BIG mistake here alienating guests in this manner? We travel to NYC on business regularly and have never had the treatment we received at the Standard. They need to take a hint from their name and seriously raise them!!!!! Never ever will visit this pretentious establishment again!

So we were a little early checking in as we arrived on a red eye flight from LAX. Most hotels would make sure they do their best to get your room and hurry up, instead we ended up checking in after 1pm. Room wasnt ready even on time.That being said, going into the room I was shocked even by NYC standards just how small the rooms were... tiny!!! but at least the bath was good.The staff were stiff and a little cold, with too much attitude on reception.At $500 usd a night room not value... if you can find a deal around $300 I would then say its worth this.

living close to nyc does have benefits. but this past weekend i stayed at the high line standard hotel and boy was i happy! VIP Vacations was so helpful in finding a great place with tons to do! Jennifer at VIP ensured me that my girlfriend and I would have great time there for my girlfriends birthday. We ice skated, had dinner at the standard grill and danced the night away at le bain the club upstairs in the hotel! What a great weekend in NYC. The food was amazing i suggest the million dollar chicken for 2!!

Book this hotel if only for the amazing views.... Luckily was staying here as the other half was on business (could not afford to pay the room rate!) but loved the hotel. Yes the reception and communal areas including the restaurant and bar areas get crowded and a little crazy, but the room is modern and well finished and with amazing view downtown to the Freedom Tower or if on the other side of the hotel, uptown towards the Empire State Building. The bathroom is quirky.. a kind of shutter/blind to spare your blushes with your travelling companion in the bedroom is all that separates you as you shower (so if only friends, be warned...) but the main attraction are the floor to ceiling windows. Much time spent just laying on the bed gazing out at the Hudson River and the changing skyline from morning to night. There are fabulous bars up on the roof too.

We stayed here for a single night on a brief trip to catch a show. The design is eye-catching. We stayed in a standard queen room on the 13th floor. Great views of midtown and the Empire State Building. Room was on the small side, but comfortable. Had no problems with noise. The crowds trying to get to the club on the top floor made for a slightly longer than desirable wait for an elevator, but everyone was in such a jovial mood it made for some interesting elevator talk. Speaking of the club, the views are spectacular, but we went for pre-dinner drinks so getting in was not an issue.

Fantastic, unpretentious but very cool hotel! Staff were fantastic - we particularly liked Zachary our waiter and the bar staff in the grill. It is a great destination hotel as well as a good restaurant/bar to stop in. Location is great as you feel you are in a great part of town!

Nice trendy hotel but it misses perfection in many aspects such as the rooms, service. The fantastic top view bar was closed for private events and this was part of the reason to stay here. Rooms are interesting but rather small and not very well layer out. Nice place to stay but under delivering for the 'spoiled' business traveler at a premium price.

Stayed at The Standard 1 night with my husband. Room #1304. Nice sized room with a king bed. Was very happy with everything about the hotel. They have a small ice skating rink out front. Enjoyed sitting outside and watching the skaters. Overall, a very nice experience.

Stayed here for four nights last week. Got an ok rate - $365/night room only for a deluxe king. I really enjoyed staying here. It's not a perfect hotel - there's no proper wardrobe or any drawers, for example, but it's fun. I had a room with views onto the Hudson, and down to the highline below. Spacious enough for one person, but if I was coming back as a couple, I would try to book one of the corner rooms or a studio. Huge soaking tub with a rainfall shower, and ok in-house toiletries. Lots of mirrors in the room for checking yourself out.. Had room service one night - not great - a bit cold and only so-so taste-wise. Great drinks menu though. Had breakfast in the Grill on the ground floor each morning - quiet, fast, tasty. Used the gym a couple of times - it's worth going to just for the views. Not so great in terms of free weights, but ok selection of cardio machines. Location is great, I guess depending in what you want. Personally, I love the meatpacking district, and the hotel is also a short walk from Chelsea. Lots of great restaurants nearby- Pastis, and also this place the hotel recommended, called Willow Road. Service was good. My only note would be to recommend only modifying room bookings online, rather than over the phone - I spoke to a reservation agent twice to make some changes to my booking, but when I logged in the day before arrival, I saw nothing had been changed. And my other gripe would be with the slightly shabby-looking bedspread/eiderdown. One of the highlights of the stay - the bar on the top floor. I had a great time with some colleagues- and I'm not even that much a fan of bars. Or fun. Wonderful live music, more great views, and a good cocktail menu. The hotel feels a bit like a younger version of the Andaz - which I also like. Would definitely go back - but book a larger room next time.

I stayed here during christmas and thats what I found:1-Location is great, in the meat packing district, close to hip places and trendy restaurants.2-The view from my room was amazing.3-hotel staff were very friendly in general.4- room service was grommet and delicious.5- The hotel seemed a little worn out, carpets and wall paint.6- The hotel was very busy, to the point of being uncomfortable, it was noisy most of my stay. And when I mentioned that at check-out, they wished I expressed that earlier so they could change my room. So that was nice.7- I got an upgrade but my room was still on the smaller scale.

Sweetest hotel in NYC. Rooms are so clean and comfortable, with fantastic views no matter where you are. The skating rink adds the perfect amount of whimsy to a very posh hotel. The service is perfect especially those who greet you at the front desk. They are accommodating and professional. We were there during the holidays and despite how busy it was outside there was a calmness at the The Standard. They have it just right!

We had a three-day stay we booked thru Jetsetter and, while the staff was quite accommodating and friendly in spite of our discounted room rate, I think the hotel itself leaves a lot to be desired. The pros: as noted, nice staff; very nice beds; great location. The cons: extremely small rooms with not enough space to hang a coat and clothing for two adults; too few outlets; no desk or station for computer; bathroom okay but no robe hooks and too few outlets, along with extremely little counter space; WAY too loud from the nightclub above, well into the wee hours; and, last, but not least, after 10pm, you must leave the Boom Boom Room and see if you're cool enough for re-entry, which is utterly ridiculous. It's flat-out dumb to be treated this way as a paying hotel guest. We were also informed that we were not allowed to bring our coats into the BBR (really?!?). I'm just going to say that neither my husband nor I look like we're poised to steal cocktail napkins or straws, so this is just mystifying, as well as being extremely annoying. I would not return.

I had an excellent birthday stay at The Standard High Line. My entire experience from check-in to check-out was amazing! Christina, the front desk agent that checked me in, was very friendly and welcoming. Thanks to the manager, Paul, for the amazing upgrade and birthday amenity. What a treat! I never got to meet the room attendant but she was kind enough to make sure my room was spic-n-span and respected my belongings. The bell staff was great too to bring my pizza delivery personally to my room. This was the best birthday I've ever had and it's all thanks to the lovely staff at The Standard High Line.

6 night stay. It was great. The bed extremely comfortable and the room just sizeable enough for new york (as if you will spend much time there anyway!). Once used to the window exposure it was fine. We heard some mild music noise on the first night, but think it was probably from across the road as opposed to the bar on top.The door staff were excellent. They produced an excellent service. The front staff were also excellent. The meals at the restaurant were excellent as were the cocktails sampled at various bars there.The boom boom room on top allowed us to see one of the best sunsets.Downsides - very few. The waitstaff in the boom boom room seemed to spend more time discussing social things amongst themselves rather than paying attention. All in all though we loved it and will be back

I stayed here on business in October for 3 nights. The room per night was very pricey and it didn't include breakfast just room only. The room I was put in was great I loved the huge bath and cosy bed. The size of the room was just fine for me although I can see why people may complain that there a little small if there is more than one person staying in it. The view out of my window was of waist land which was a little disappointing considering the window was floor to ceiling. The mini bar in the room was the biggest I've ever seen in a hotel room although I didn't dare take anything out of it as it all seemed over priced! The roof top bar is worth a visit it has beautiful views over New York especially at sun set.

I stay at this hotel two or three times a month depending on travel and I really wouldn't stay anywhere else in NY, I would and have recommended this hotel to lots of my friends and work colleagues. Ok so why do I love it?!Firstly the location, it's in a great part of town with a really cool vibe and close to everything I need, I also run in the mornings and being on the west side it's close to the Hudson so I run down to WTC which has just great views. The beds are the most comfortable hotel beds that I have ever slept in just what you need when the jet lag kicks in. Rooms with great views, I prefer an end room facing the Hudson although the city views are just as good a high floor is a must! I'd also recommend a room with a bath that over looks the city they are so cool. Reception staff really welcoming with a "Welcome back Mr Johnson" just what you expect from a hotel of this standard, nothing seems to be too much trouble, also really accommodating with last minute change, I made several changes because my plans kept changing and they just changed with me with no hassle (thanks Joseph)Check out is a breeze with great attention to detail, you get that great service till you get into the taxi, even the bell hop boys are cool and rather cute!Roof top bar is a must, great cocktail amazing views and again just a really cool vibe, can get a little chilly depending on the time of year summer night are so cool. Restaurants in the hotel are really good, pizzas if you want something easy (they are really good) and the other more formal restaurant is also great I'd book a table tho. Thing I'd recommend are duck meatballs and the breakfast menu is just as you'd expect from a good NY restaurant. The best mini bar is great, just really quirky and fun, you'll know what I mean when you see it. Great location for shopping and other great restaurants. Even the lifts are really cool and again you'll know what I mean when you're in one. I'm really looking forward to my next visit which will be in a couple of weeks So to sum up this review, for me this is one of the coolest hotels in the city, I wouldn't hesitate in recommending it to anyone I look forward to staying there every time I go and never leave thinking I had a bad stay. #reallycoolhotel#cooltrendyvibe

Stayed here over the NYE period and had the best time The location is awesome, just a walk away from delicious food and great bars. The view from the hotel was spectacular and complimented by the luxurious room and great hotel services. I was particularly impressed by the front office manager Joseph that made every effort to make my stay a delight.
