I have stayed at the Standard Highline several times while in town for business and combining the trip with a little pleasure. I have always had the most unbelievable stays at this hotel! Not only are the facilities beautiful and the views amazing, but the service at the hotel really sets it above the rest. Everyone from the front desk to the bell men to even the cleaning staff that I ran into were nothing but pleasant and helpful. The location cannot be beat. It is on the Highline, which is both a beautiful little park to meander through and it is also conveniently located near the West Side Highway. The Standard has a number of bikes that they allow you to take out for the day. I have to say one of my favorite New York experiences ever has been to bike along the West Side Hwy bike path up through Central Park. That is if you want to leave the immediate area around the hotel. The hotel is located in the Meat Packing district , which is an insanely hip area filled with fun bars, restaurants and a dangerous amount of good shopping. The Chelsea Markets are also right around the corner and make for a good time. Overall, I would 100% recommend this hotel to any friend or family member staying in Manhattan and I know that I will be back!

Amazing views, we stayed on the 14th floor with lovely Hudson River views, always a discussion on which are the best views city or river, I think river during the day and city at night.Rooms are small and beautifully decorated but there's enough space to stuff all your things and still have space to walk around.Amazing bar on the rooftop!Be aware of the noise on Friday and Saturday, specially on the top floors, we could hear the music perfectly in our room.The location in the Meatpacking District is perfect with lots of shops, restaurants, cafés and clubs to enjoy.If you are coming to NYC to enjoy all of the pleasures the city has to offer, this is the right hotel, if you want to enjoy a quiet stay this is not the right place for you! I'll definitely come back for more!

The design and décor is incredible, as is the staff. The front desk staff was so helpful and gave great suggestions... and we never had an issue with catching a cab with the prompt door guy! Our stay at the Standard made for an amazing trip to NYC! Part business part pleasure -- highly recommend staying here!!

My husband and I are big fans of the Hotel Tonight app. When I checked the app promptly at 9 am I was super excited to see The Standard as one of the choices. I had stayed at The Standard once before without my husband and was looking forward to sharing the experience with him to celebrate my birthday. Upon check in, Paul at the front desk was extremely friendly and helpful. Any concern that the Hotel might treat one differently for not having paid full price by using the Hotel Tonight app was quickly dissolved. He could not have been more accommodating and excited to make our stay as enjoyable as possible. Learning it was my birthday he eagerly upgraded us to a corner room. The views were exceptional!!! The room was extremely clean and the decor is modern and comfortable. The bed was heavenly as I completely enjoyed not only sleeping past 10 am but also taking a two hour nap!The location is AMAZING! The best restaurants - definitely check out the Chelsea Market (an excellent recommendation from the concierge!) Also eat at the Standard Grille and if you can go up to the Boom Boom Room the decor is out of this world!!!! The Beer Garden is a great place to go for a drink as well. The shopping in The Meat Packing is fantastic! Every brand you love has their own boutique store - also try to go to Jeffrey's for the most amazing boutique department store in NYC.All in all, we will definitely be back and keep our fingers crossed that The Standard continues its relationship with Hotel Tonight as we will always choose to stay there given the option.

I have actually stayed here many times without incident, but this past time I was conned into an upgrade so I want to share the stories so that others can be warned and know NOT TO SIGN ANYTHING without reading it carefully.I work in the area and my company frequently has employees stay here. We were having an event that night in the city and since I live in CT, we decided to spend the night in the city. I got the room on HotelTonight. When my husband got to the hotel, they offered him an upgrade for $80 a night. He immediately said no - but the woman insisted and said she would give it to him for free anyway (my guess is they ran out of the room they were supposed to give us). They told him no charge, but made him sign a few papers, which he didn't review carefully. The next day there was a charge for $93.80 on our card! I protested with Amex, but since my husband had signed, there was nothing that could be done. So please be careful about signing anything, even if they offer you a free upgrade, because it is NOT free. FYI - I don't see how the room was an upgrade anyway. It was the same tiny room I've stayed in before with a view of the parking lot on the back side of the hotel.

Standard Hotel.IS The Standard for newest, latest, most attractiven, cutting edge ? NO Not at all. It is a new standard for design and management failure. But does offer good small beds and a decent internet connection...Design: The Standard rooms so small that it is virtually impossible to place two normal suitcases and hang shirts, suits or dresses for a weekend stay. The shower so small and horribly designed that there is no room for a shower curtain or door. Water, water everywhere. A Bavarian hoopa hoopa bar in the ground floor retail maze including dirndls en bellies. Is this is the top of trendiness? Maybe in Munich anno 1845Comfort:Yes! Good beds. Not the rock hard standard of some pseudo hotels. The Standard beds are a small standard. A sort of dwarf-king size like in Snow White… But at least sleepable. Yes, someone was thinking. The bed comfort is the only reason why any one would really pay for this hotel. The beds are good. Hoteliers everywhere, this is the Standard to follow.Quiet:It seems for some victims that a throbbing bass beat is necessary everywhere. Some even wear there DJ headphones to bed. NOT at the Standard. At the Standard all-night bass beats are included in every room. The city that never sleeps. Now we know why. The Standard’s own anti-sleep standard. A club on the 18th floor. Guests in the hotel, however are NOT welcome. Unless they wish to settle their bill at the bar and then follow the terse instructions to go outside and wait in the rain and cold to be ‘selected for re-entry’ Now this is the standard that the real victims of trend traps are seeking? Facilities: Working internet: perfect for seeking a good hotel alternative or to write your Trip Advisor notes...A good gym: to work off your frustrations, or to change clothes to go out. As there is no space in your guest room to do this. Good mirrors in the gym. Thank you for the Standard.Pricing: The price of a room. Just slightly higher than a real hotel with proper room comfort, trendy design, great views and genuine service. In addtion to the exhorbitant room price: A three micro-wave mini-ravioli appetizer: US$27.00 plus tax and service: $35.00 on a mini plate with a paper napkin. Fabulous view included. The Standard. Attitude:Drop a few hundred dollars at the 18th floor bar or even a few $1000 and you are sent to the street below to get screened for access to the throbbing bass club on the ….18th floor. The real trend victims will love this Standard of gracious service. Keep it coming.On check out: “Was everything ok” asked the trendy reception manager? Not quite what I expected.” Was my honest answer. To which the Standard reply: “see you next time!”And last but certainly not least; The person at the Standard whose task it is to respond to The Trip Advisor…. So many ways to put a positive spin on a negative experience. You deserve the Standard prize for deceptive writing. Second Standard in NYC??? Are there so many victims?, or will the second Standard be a better Standard. Watch Trip Advisor for more…

We really like the location of this hotel. In addition to being at the Hi Line Park, much more importantly it is in the meat packing district which has great restaurants like Patisserie and great shopping. One of the best neighborhoods to walk around. The hotel restaurant is also excellent and the hotel is great.

From the moment I arrived through that revolving yellow door at The Standard High Line late last year, I realised that I'd arrived somewhere pretty special.Though it might look a little 'plain jane' from the outside, but as is so often the case in life, it's most definitely what's on the inside that counts. And what's on the inside are friendly, courteous, well-humoured staff throughout, funky fittings and fixtures, a well-stocked gift shop, lifts with TVs that transport you to an alternate universe and an intimate bar. And that's all before you get to the rooms. Mine, a Junior Liberty Suite, featured floor to ceiling glass windows looking out onto the Hudson River. From various vantage points within the room, I could see the Statue Of Liberty, the Freedom Tower and - around a corner - the Empire State Building. Spectacular.The king-size bed was comfortable, the pillows were the softest I've EVER slept on, the room has a unique - and pleasing - scent and the temperature was always spot on, despite the sub-zero conditions outside.There was a gorgeous stand-alone bath, a glass shower (albeit with no privacy screen - so know your roommate well) and plenty of sofa space.I dined twice in the Standard Grill downstairs and not only was the food of the highest standard (pardon the pun), the service was also first rate.There was also a mini ice-skating rink at the front entrance, with a chalet next to it serving hot chocolates... the perfect way to spend a winter hour or two.Yes, there's a nightclub upstairs which can result in a few thumping basslines working their way down, but who'd travel to a big city expecting complete silence? I take earplugs wherever I travel.Taxis are easily accessible at the front of the building, there are some great shops and restaurants within metres of the door, the High Line walk is literally beneath the hotel and Chelsea Market is just two blocks to the north. I can't recommend The Standard High Line highly enough. A spectacular start to an extremely memorable trip. Five star all the way.

The hotel is built right over the top of the High Line park in the meatpacking district of Manhattan. Great spot for shopping, fun restaurants and night clubs if you are so inclined. The weather was miserable when I arrived and a hotel bellman picked me out for help and assisted me to the front door of the hotel. Very nice touch, especially given that the door is not so obvious.The place is European chic and I did feel like I should try and speak with an accent to get service. Everyone was warm and helpful. First class from the time I arrived until a late checkout which was also nice.The room was a bit small, but quite nice. I had a room overlooking the Empire State Building which is all lit up for the holiday season. The place seemed quite comparable to the Andaz hotels, although not quite as nice.

Surprise first time visit to NY and staff were helpful, even upgraded us to a jnr suite, decor flawless scandinavian 70's design and no query too small. Great location for walking round NY and plenty of shops and restaurants close by. Would highly recommend for couples wanting a banging good time

On a positive note, our room on the 11th floor was well proportioned and had an awesome view of the city skyline, with the Empire State Building dominating th skyline with it's green and red Christmas lights. The room was well laid out with a nice table with bulkhead style seating and a separete chair where you could sit to eat or sip wine and absorb the amazing view. The bed was also super comfortable and the glass shower added a quirky element to the room. It did however repeatably steam up the external windows of the room, despite having the fan on the maximum setting. We could only 'unfrost' the widows by repeatedly opening the window - not ideal in a New York winter.Unfortunately the service let the hotel down considerably. Our one room service request over four nights never arrived and our one interaction with the concierge, who undertook to find us a a local dinner reservation for New Years Eve, took three follow ups (over 2 days) both over the phone and in person before a vacancy was found in the Standard Grill (One of the hotels own restuarants) despite being previously told was completely booked out.The bar on th 18th floor has some good views but it took us half an hour to get a drink. This included trying to attract the attention of the waitresses roaming the floor (we were seated at a table) and also trying to queue up at the bar. It seemed pretty obvious that the bar targets the trendy Meatpacking 'wannabe' crowd, rather than guests.Unfortunately, as mentioned by previous reviewers, there is now a building site beside the hotel on the city side and we were woken each morning, apart from a public holiday, to a jackhammer pounding away at 7.00am.The hotel lacks warmth and friedliness and we were constantly reminded by staff that the meatpacking district is the 'happening and in' place in NYC at the moment. Maybe they should forget that, drop the attitude and concentrate on providing a better service so that guests will return.....Oh, the doghnuts from the stall outside the front of the hotel next to the ice skating rink were amazing, best ones we have ever had! So good, we went back for seconds the next day.Would not stay here again.

I am telling you now that The Standard - High Line is the *best* hotel in NYC. The staff, including Paul Kashman, Amal Bijoux, and others, are fantastic. They are helpful, they smile, and they hook you up with great service. The views from this hotel are the best in the city. The food @ The Standard Grill is great, too. I advise you to try this place. Ask for Paul Kashman when you reserve a room. His team is the best.

Pros are great location in meatpacking district, great top floor bar, but sometimes a bit pretentious, lovely food in restaurant.Cons are...well I can't think of any apart from its not cheap and the bar pretentiousness as mentioned above.

Great location. Potentially a top hotel. Staff were warm and friendly in the main. However, some were clearly judging the value of guests on appearance (or in the case of the rooftop bar by footwear). It was bemusing to see it go wrong a couple of times. Be aware that a new building is starting to be erected next to the hotel, so factor in a bit of noise from sunrise to sunset.

Hotel is very hip and in an awesome location right in the Meatpacking area of NYC. Close walk to the West Village. Check in was very easy and the room was a decent size for NYC. As others have noticed, the shower has a window right into the main room so be wary of that based off who you are traveling with. Went to the rooftop bar which was a good time, albeit slightly pretentious. Had a nice time and will look to return next time I'm in NYC.

Superb location in an outstanding part of the city. The hotel has great views, top restaurants, outstanding rooftop bar and highly professional and yet laid back staff. The view from the gym is world class and worth staying for that alone. Enjoy

The Standard is the ultimate in cool; understated and somewhat stark, the air filled with the scent of amber candles and the sound of foreign accents. I was set for the place to be snotty, with chilly "better than you" service. But, from the valet parkers to the doormen to the coffee bar server to the front desk clerk, everyone was cordial and welcoming. The Standard takes price in its chi-chi rep but no one takes themselves too seriously. Fabulous accommodations , low-key, super clean furnishings and the most comfortable hotel bed I've been in in a long time. The room was lacking a few things: 1) an in room Keurig-type coffee maker that's become derigeur, 2) a generous selection of bathroom amenity extras guests have come to expect from high end hotels -- here, there was only shampoo, conditioner and lotion -- and 3) drywall between the shower and the bed. In our queen room, only a pane of shower glass separated those in the douche from others in the room so unless you like putting on a Show for your roommate, trust him when he says he won't peek or have no modesty, you may have a problem. Overnight, the room was blissfully quiet (except for the confused drunken woman who banged on our door in error at 3am ... But that can happen anywhere..). Luckily, we had an early morning because construction across Washington Street started bright and early. It is a very long term project that soundproof window glass can't muffle. But, that's NYC and we weren't bothered. This winter, the hotel set up an ice skating rink in front of the building which was a real treat. Great Meatpacking District location, just south of Chelsea

So my friends and I are staying here right now. No running water because of some disaster last night upstairs. No sleep because of all the leaking water. And to top it off, no help from the front desk after several calls. So, here we are, no way to take a shower or even brush our teeth after a sleepless night. What little water we have is coming out of the tap brown. The nice maintenance guy who came to check out our complaint was the only positive. What a great start to the new year! Thanks management for caring about your guests.

The room I stayed in had a great view, not spacious but that's expected/acceptable in NYC. It was very clean and an overall good room experience. The location was also very ideal. However, when I stay at high-end hotels I expect a certain type of service and respect -- and did not get that at The Standard Highline. No one was even there to get our bags as we first arrived. Overall, I was a little turned off by that and will most likely not be staying there again. If you are looking for a wonderful hotel in a great location, I would recommend The Trump Soho.

Had a great time at the Standard High Line. Would have loved a view of the Hudson, but ended up with a view of the Empire State Building and it was lit up in holiday colors - very cool view from the window.There is still a construction site on the non-Hudson side underneath the hotel - I didn't really mind, but some people might be offput. Stayed on a Saturday so there was no construction going on as far as I can tell, but I imagine some weekdays will have noise.The skating rink is small but fun - great for kids. If you are expecting to get any speed - go to Chelsea Piers a little ways away (though it's not outdoors!). It was too warm to use it while I stayed but I've used it before and enjoyed it - the boozy hot chocolate they serve there is highly recommended.The peekaboo shower is definitely couples-only.. if you are going with someone who you would rather not have you see take a shower, make sure they are out of the room at that time!Ended up ordering room service and it was surprisingly good - the simple pasta dish was very tasty, and the artic char was a decent value and tasty as well.Perhaps my favorite part of the hotel was the funky music/video they have playing in the elevator.

The Standard High Line is definitely a unique hotel that hits the modern trend. Food is quite good as is the service. Everyone I encountered was extremely polite and helpful and not in a forced way.Their catering abilities for onsite parties/functions are also very spot on. The area is of course very historic being literally on the High Line was a treat. The views were wonderful also.This was a quick trip for me to NYC for business and we did a block at the hotel due to a company function being there. For 2 nights the room was fine, if I had to do a full business week or 2 there I would probably not be inclined to do so. The work area in the room is great but just general manuevering and settling into the room not so much.It was literally living out of the suitcase, the way the room is structured you really can't settle in, at least the way the room I had was structured.In addition due to the great popularity of this hotel and its restaurants/bars, just popping in for a quick easy meal or drink after work or arriving in, not really an option. Room service was the only way to go.Would I stay here again, for a personal trip possibly, for business not likely. Mixed review I know.

We spent Christmas in NYC at the Standard High Line in the meatpacking district. We've been to NYC a few times, but this was our first time staying in this area - it was right up our alley - in general a quieter spot in the city, on top of the High Line, a block from the L subway line, and plenty to see and do nearby.The hotel itself was good, but not great. We got a deal on Jetsetter, and upon arriving early in the morning, were able to get in to our room before noon. Unfortunately they forgot to bring our luggage up 'within 5 minutes' as promised, but an hour later when we reminded them, it came right away. There's free wifi, the room was a good size for New York, and the giant tub was a bonus. Note that it's very easy to see in the rooms from outside, so use the blackout shade when you need privacy, and hopefully you're not shy in your room because there's a window between the shower and bedroom area. The bed was huge and comfy, and the fully equipped gym is open 24/7 and has a great view. The hotel is a noisy place - there was construction right next door which included jackhammering early in the morning, and being on the 15th floor, even though we were assured it was a 'quieter' floor, we were able to hear the party-thumping bass from the top floor on the Saturday night of our stay, and the doors are pretty thin, too. So just a warning if noise is an issue for you. Service was fine for us, but not above and beyond as I was expecting in a boutique hotel of this sort. There's no coffee/tea in your room, and the price of a coffee in the lobby is kinda silly ($4 for a regular coffee!), but Chelsea Market is nearby for some good grub. We really liked the area overall, and the hotel was nice, but a few small things and basic service improvements could change it in to great hotel.

This is a fun hotel, in a great location. The rooms have floor-to-ceiling windows with super views. There are several restaurants & bars on premise - street-level as well as on the rooftop. One important thing to note is that the bathroom bath/shower is fully exposed to the room - there is only a glass wall between the bed/living area and the bathroom - great for a bath with nighttime city views, but no privacy whatsoever if you need it.

The Standard Hotel is a wonderful place for a romantic weekend in the city. The rooms have floor to ceiling windows which afford a great view of the city. Up on top of the Hotel is the private bar which has amazing panoramic views, elegant architectural details, fireplaces, live music and an incredible wait staff. The bed in our room was like floating on air and the pillows were straight from heaven. We had intended to go ice skating at the hotel rink located right in front of the hotel, but mother nature warmed up the city and the ice melted sadly. We had brunch at the hotel and it was delicious, also good waitstaff. We had two rooms this trip, one for us and one for our children. We all had a wonderful time in the city. The staff at the front desk was very helpful and gave us directions which thankfully did not get us lost. We had a lovely walk on the highline, walked through Chelsea Markets which is lots of fun and then we finished off with a visit to Pink Berry! I would definately stay at this hotel again and highly reccomend it to one and all. This hotel is catering to people who love good service and consistent quality. We had checked out at noon and then asked the hotel to store our bags while we went to the theater. When we were returning to the hotel, we called ahead and the bellman met us at our car, with our bags and helped us load up for the trip home. Perfect timing and a great trip. 5 Stars!!!

We love the Standard Grill and had eaten there a few times but the hotel was a disappointment. We weren't that high up but even so it was impossible to avoid the music from the nightclub which kept us awake. Stood on a pin left on the floor of the room. For the price it would have been nice to have a bed you could get in and out of both sides of. Views and location terrific, and the Grill is great for both dinner and breakfast, but you can eat there and stay elsewhere

So stayed while our place was being renovated, room was tight but otherwise real nice and there were some great food choices in hotel, even stopped by boomboom room! The beer garden was also fun and the food there was great.

The Standard does almost everything well. It's hip, interesting walkable neighborhood and clean comfortable rooms. They had two major flaws with food and beverage. First they rent out parts of the hotel for private events, not a big deal except due to that we had to walk outside to access the hotel restaurant. It was about 20 degrees and I was not happy that I had to go back to my room to get a jacket and walk around the block outside the hotel to the hotel restaurant to accommodate extra revenue for the hotel. Not cool!Second issue; In the early morning it's almost impossible to get a coffee. I left for work and was told in the lobby that if I wanted coffee to order room service. BTW it was a 30+ minute wait for room service. Needless to say I could not wait. Several other business people were struggling with the same problem. While the lack of morning coffee is not a deal killer it's kind of a joke....Regardless I would recommend staying here, the value is great, the people are pretty and the area has amazing restaurants in walking distance. No place is perfect and for the price/location I can work around their gaps....

Stayed at the Standard High Line for one night on a recent business trip. Located in the meat-packing district on the western side of lower Manhattan. Reception staff were friendly and helpful. Beautiful view of the Hudson from my room - the huge windows are fantastic Bed is a sort of Scandanavian style, low-to-the-ground bed....very comfortable. There is a popular nightclub on the top floor which seems to get busy......but didn't bother me at all. Adjacent to the High Line park - very convenient. I would certainly stay here again.

So I tagged along with my husband on a business trip. His company only picks the trendiest, coolest, hippest places. This place is GREAT! Yes the rooms are a little tight, but aren't they all in NY?!?! Yes there is a "nudie" shower. If you are looking for family friendly this is not the place, however, they are family friendly. My 3 and 4 year old LOVE it here. I kinda feel embarrassed walking in the halls with my kids when I pass by the trendy singles on the way to the club. The staff here is AWESOME!! My kids have not been to happy with all the fancy meals, and just wanted a good ol' fashion mac and cheese, so the lady at the front desk, took our kraft single and heated it up for us. Then she had a microwave delivered to our room to use for the rest of the week. When we checked in, we asked about a roll away bed, I think they wanted to laugh at us, but the front desk staff was so nice and wonderful she gave us a complimentary upgrade to a King Superior ( I don't think I would have survived a week in something smaller with my two kiddos). My kids LOVE the crazy video in the elevator. We have temporarily lost our room key while getting on the elevator, but someone has always helped us out. The cleaning staff is good. The front desk staff is helpful and nice and friendly. The "guys out front"( bell man!?!?) are THE BEST!!! They walk to the door and open it for us ( yes, we have a double stroller and barely fit in any establishment in NY), they help us with the cabs, so friendly and I would want them to marry any one of my single girlfriends. I could go on about this AWESOME place... I would stay here again (preferably with out my children and heck maybe even my husband ... hahaha). So if you are cool rich and single come here.. IF you are with kids and husband come here and pretend you are cool rich and single! Great Atmosphere with an amazing STAFF!!! I really don't want to leave...

We stayed on the 6th floor, the room is OK and except for the view nothing special really. The bed was comfortable. On the 18th Floor there is a bar with great views. Next to the bar, on the same floor is the Club, which starts around 10 PM, but if you want to get in you have to go down, go outside and stand in line (!) Even if you are a hotel guest and just spent 200 dollar on booze in the bar. Ridiculous! The music is loud until 4 AM.. Expect to hear the noise -even on the 6th floor-, but the hotel staff will provide you with complimentary earplugs. We expected a design hotel, but a biergarten with hoempapa music ???(brrr). In short, the Standard is highly overrated.

This is the place ! I love it. It's expensive but beautiful. Of course it's one of the trendiest place in the city, so a lot of hipsters, rich and noisy kids but this is why you booked this hotel too ! I stayed there many times and I'm going again soon. The view, the view, the view ! I love the Boom Boom room (top of the standard), the restaurant is great too and the service is amazing. The staff of the hotel is really pro and friendly (I'm always expecting a mean staff there and it's always the contrary). This is a party hotel not the Plaza (hehe lucky you it's slighly cheaper). If you want to experience a true new york experience I strongly recommend to give it a try. Don't worry if you don't have the trendiest clothes, you are in Meatpacking so you can just use the wonderful elevators and go shoppppppping !

i have stayed in many hotels over the years, and the first rule is to always understand the target market of a hotel. the standard is a great hotel if you want to be at a place that is always the life of the party, with lots of great things to do and lots of beautiful people. it's NOT a place for total and utter bliss and relaxation, or divine service.i checked in after 3 pm but my room wasn't ready. but the front desk rep, katelin (i am guessing on the spelling of her name) mentioned that the room would soon be ready and just needed the final signoff by engineering because something had been reported as problematic and had been fixed. katelin also mentioned that since i was going to be in the hotel for five nights, this room was worth waiting for. bonus points for that. i was starving, so i left my luggage with the valet and asked katelin to call when the room was ready. this being the meatpacking district, there were plenty of options in walking distance, not the least of which was the hotel's own very reasonably priced standard grill.i got a call 30 to 40 minutes later, and i came back, and katelin had the keys ready, saying the luggage would be brought up.room itself was cool in a funky way. nothing is gonna be big in manhattan, and this was no exception. but it was essentially a pseudo-corner room (not really a corner room, but had the views of a corner room), and it had a nice sort of modern bench seat and table to work from. i'd describe the bench seat as a sort of corner booth you see in a restaurant. funky, but very cool.closet space is minimal here. drawers? forget about it. you end up hanging up what you need to, and the rest will sit in your bag. so that's a negative if you travel with lots of crap.the other niggle? the valet took freaking FOREVER to find my bag. i made two separate calls after being in the hotel room, and it still took about 40 minutes to get my bag. really frustrating. i know this isn't the four seasons, but next time just leave my bag downstairs, and i will get it myself. i don't need someone to send me my bag 40 minutes late and then look at me as if i need to tip them (which i did, by the way).room service is from the standard grill, and it's gonna be more expensive than typical room service (though probably fair for manhattan), and the portions are good. i ate twice at the standard grill during this trip, and both times were good.the toiletries aren't really that great, but whatever...you can go down to CVS two avenue blocks away on 14th street/8th avenue if you are picky.one other thing...if you are traveling with someone who you are not comfortable seeing naked, don't go here. the shower has no curtains and it is an open-view window. so if you are watching TV, you are gonna see the other person showering. fine with me, since this was business, and every girl that came over was a girl who was comfortable with me seeing her naked showering, but if you are traveling with a buddy, this could get awkward.overall, it was a good room, and i had no problems sleeping. you aren't gonna get exquisite furniture here, but if you want modern boutique and a very cool room (one that would be fun to share with a date or a lover because of the open-view shower), you could do a lot worse.i'd be back.

Great service on check in, very friendly staff and nicely styled rooms although wet room style bathroom just resulted in lots of water on the floor. This was somewhat annoying although I was perfectly happy there. Liked the location, lots of cabs around, nice bars and restaurants.

Having read a few reviews before my trip I had a good idea of what to expect from the Standard, High Line. Major selling points for me were:- Having emailed ahead to request a mid level floor (for a view without the club noise) and a 'tub with a view', when I arrived after a long and delayed Amtrak ride, I was greeted warmly by Irina who happily accommodated my request by allocating me a corner room on the 12th floor, with stunning views of both the Hudson River and the Empire State Building. - The view was just as good from the shower and tub, and really is worth every penny.- The hotel enjoys a great location above the Highline Park, a stones throw from Chelsea Market, well served by the A,C, E and L trains and a pleasant walk from Greenwich Village, SoHo, Tribeca and LES. - There were always cabs available outside.- The room is well stocked with essential toiletries, a varied minibar, radio, TV, good linens and bath robes. - Complimentary Wifi throughout the hotel- Everything was perfectly clean; the heating A/C is easy to use and despite the high floor you can open the windows (safely). - On floor 12 I experienced no street noise and minimal noise (a very feint thump thump of bass) only on one evening.- Room service was quick, friendly and efficientWhere I felt the hotel falls short is- I wasn't surprised to hear that the rooftop bars were closed, which was a bit disappointing, but there's plenty else to do in the area; and the view is equally good from the room. (I'd expect a top class hotel to keep this space open to guests at all times)- No complimentary bottled water - such a basic thing, which doesn't cost a lot but makes guests feel looked after (particularly for Brits who are used to tea and coffee making facilities in room)- Speaking of which, a coffee maker/ Nespresso machine wouldn't go amiss- No turn down service (far from essential, but does make you feel looked after on holiday)- A moot point - but the TV was slightly mistuned and could have greatly benefitted from a listings function. Plus the selection of on demand movies was poor. I guess New York is entertainment enough though!In summary - would I stay again? Absolutely yes - the Standard Highline is in a great location with unbeatable views, and nicely appointed rooms. As a 4* it is very cool and comfortable, so it's achieving what it sets out to do. I just think perhaps they are missing a trick, as with a few little extra touches it could be a really great guest experience. I'd love to see them take a leaf out of the Andaz's book and offer complimentary coffee and soft drinks in room, and a wine hour in the lobby.

Excellent concierge services, great hotel, very comfortable room, easy temperature control in room, super comfy bed and soft pillows, very cool vibe in the hotel and restaurants and love the The Line walk that goes through the Standard -just perfect! Gym is good too. And of course, the Boom Room is spectacular!

We stayed in this hotel, not because of the tiny rooms at $600 a night as there are far better rooms in NYC for that price, but for the cool top floor bar and roof top called 'le Bain'. Le Bain is the main feature of the hotel, prominent on the website and all advertised heavily - it was closed for private functions, not for one night, but for the entire 7 night stay.No one said anything at booking, checkin or during the stay. The management of the hotel could care less and offered nothing. Over half the amenity space (the principle attraction) of this hotel is closed to paying guests.We are asking for a part refund and won't be returning.Rude!

I live in New York and just wanted to get away for the weekend. Look up this hotel and was in the perfect location. However the best part was I didn't have to leave the hotel. All of the delicious food, night clubs and bars were all there in the hotel plaza. Even an ice skating rink. The staff were so accommodating anything we needed was received promptly. I would like to thank Paul Kashman for all the professionalism and his endearing personality. He made our stay that much better. Adam the concierge was also amazing. I would stay there any time I decide for a get away. Beautiful views of the Freedom tower, Empire State Building and East River. Rooms modern and spacious. This was an impeccable experiences.

The best part about staying at the Standard is the location. You're right next to the Highline, the Chelsea Market, great restaurants and within walking distance to Union Square, SOHO, Chelsea and many other great neighborhoods in New York. The biergarden is the other highlight - it's adjacent to the hotel and $12 will buy you a pint of beer and a pretzel (not bad for New York). There's a gym on the 17th floor, but only 2 of the treadmills were working. It's very clean and overlooks the Hudson.The downside to the hotel is that the rooms are small and the hotel is loud (there's a club on the 18th floor and I could hear music in my room until 4am and I was on the 10th floor). Also, I stayed here with a friend and the bathroom offers little privacy. There's a glass wall between the shower and the bedroom area (the hotel will put a curtain up for you upon request); however, there's no door to the bathroom (only for the toilet). The other thing I noticed is that the tub was not super clean (there was a ring of dirt around the tub when showering) and the bathroom didn't have a fan.

We booked this hotel on a friend's recommendation for a five night stay in NYC. It is right on the edge of the peninsula, so has great (in fact, stunning) views over the Hudson in one direction and midtown Manhattan in the other.We were on the 14th foor in a superior king room with direct views to the Empire State Building - it was a sight you would just not tire of seeing. The room was well configured to make use of the space, and had a separate seating area which was nice for a longer stay. There was not much in the way of storage space but this didn't bother us (we could hang up the odd item of clothing that really needed it; we tend not to fully unpack when we travel anyway). The bed was big and very confortable. The bathroom was also generous but I can imagine some people would be put off the glass wall between the bath/shower and bedroom which meant you could still enjoy the view whilst you were in the bathroom (the toilet itself was behind a door mind you - that might have been one step too far!).The location of the hotel was great for us, a few blocks from 14th Street subway which gave us great (quick and easy) transport links but away from the main tourist areas which might have become overwhelming if you didn't have a hotel elsewhere to escape from it all. It is also on the edge of the Village which was my favourite area to just wander around - that felt like real New York to me.The only downside we found was the fact that in the evening the lift (elevator) area is reconfigured to allow two of the four of the lifts to service the queue for the nightclub and bar at the top of the hotel, whilst the other two were left for hotel guests returning in the evening. The lifts themselves are quite large, so apart from the one night when the lifts appeared to stop recognising the guests' room keys to allow them to access the bedroom floors we did not have to queue. It was only that the reconfiguration was confusuing to guests who were not expecting it and every night there were, without fail, a handful of people who were trying to get to the bar / club through the hotel itself and being redirected to the queue outside and in the process clogging up the narrow corridor to the lifts. This is though a minor point and I would certainly return to this hotel.

Lobby, lounge and club are fantastic to watch people, fashion is king in this upscale and trendy place, Definitely a pretty person place fashion is important for the right look here, although I found every other guest very friendlyI had room service breakfast with a NY strip steak and egg whites. My steak was marinated perfectly roasted potatoes were firm and seasoned quality the of food outstandingMy bed was awesome with a square very firm relaxing mattressMy room faced the empire state building with an amazing views from the 12th floorTop-of-the-line hotel gym with new weights, machines, cardio equipment with stunning views from the workout room across the Hdson river to NJ and lower ManahttanVery friendly professional staffAmenities in the room were upscale, the bathroom was glass enclosed with a very deep soaking tubThe glass and the mirrors make the room a lot larger than it is in contribute to that hip chic boutique feelTwo things keep this from being a 5 star rating, first I could not get the TV to work. Secondly I found the elevators with smudges on shiney surfaces and not up to par with the rest of the property, and there were cleaning supplies left in the rest rooms by the gym

very good location, lovely food in the restaurant downstairs, a fantastic view on the hudson, friendly staff, the rooms were clean. I loved the mini bar.missed visiting the roof top bar. a lot of great restaurants just outside the hotel

It's sexy and slick and happenning. The elevator ride in itself is a trip (Trippy video art by Marco Brambilla) The neighborhood is full of hip bars and restaurants and fashion boutiques. For short term stays I absolutely love this hotel. The views are spectacular, I prefer the "City View" from 15th floor and up. Room service is excellent & the Minibar/cabinet is packed to the wazoo.

Was upgraded to a deluxe queen room which had good views but the room was small even by NY standards. Service at the desk and the off lobby bar was generally good however it really depended who was on duty. Liked the free WiFi, good location and housekeeping standards. Noisy door banging disturbs overnight use the ear plugs provided!

The upside: Great location, cool views, especially from cocktail barThe Downside: trying to sleep with noise from niteclub which as a resident I think you should NOT have to queue up in the freezing cold for, nor should you be asked for I.D. when clearly over 25 and resident in the hotel. We weren't asked for I.D. anywhere else in NY.Thanksgiving dinner in hotel's restaurant was disappointing - sloppy looking, overlooked turkey and watery mashed potato you wouldn't give a dog.

Location is fantastic. Views are spectacular, particularly from the rooftop bar which is must. You see the new World Trade Tower and the river. It has a cool vibe. There is also a closed in bar on top which is really elegant. The rooms are lacking and do not quite fit the price, interiors seem rathe dated in spots but the hotel is purposefully quirky. Try to get a room with towards the end of the building but the river to get a great view.

I previously stayed at The Standard when the hotel first opened in 2009, but recently stayed over the weekend & had an amazing stay! Literally every single person I came in contact with from the Front Desk, Housekeeping, Room Service, Guest Services, Bellman, The Standard Grill, & The Shop were super friendly, warm, hip and extremely attractive! Irina who checked me in was awesome- she set an amazing first impression, hit all the right notes, was cool, yet warm and was so nice! When I called down for assistance with my bags, Jake kindly helped me out and was very nice. Brian, my bellman, was awesome and helped me get a cab and could not have been nicer! Aubrey from Guest Services helped me out with adding a friends name onto my booking and was super sweet. I don't know who checked me out, but she was again, nice and wished me safe travels. Someone from Housekeeping even called to see if I needed service, and wished me safe travels as well. Jaris who made my reservation was very efficient! Everyone rocked! Thank you so much! I was in 1524, which had an amazing view of both the city, the Empire State building, a sliver of the High Line, West Side Highway and the Hudson River- it was beautiful! The room was very modern and cozy, with a fantastic Queen bed that was extremely comfy, an amazing rain fall shower that had insanely good pressure, a huge tub, a separate W/C, and my favorite part, the little alcove the desk and cushy seating area that was awesome to browse on my laptop, observe the views, and eat room service. The room smelled very good and was fresh and clean. Everything worked perfectly, including the heat and A/C unit. I also loved the closet with plenty of space, the shampoo and soap that smells like honey and the cool little guides that come with your key card. I really loved my room and the overall layout was just perfect. One of the highlights of my stay was the food! I went down to the bar with a great friend and we had drinks, a light meal, and some dessert, and everything was delicious and the space and atmosphere was just fantastic. The Room Service Food was so delicious! Ariana, Jason and Peter from room service were all so nice! I loved the Cobb Salad with Radish, the bread was soft and delicious, the Poached Eggs for Breakfast, the Potato Soup with homemade chips was incredibly satisfying, the Lemon Twizzle cocktail was so delicious, the Grilled Chicken Paillard was the perfect light lunch and my favorite dessert ever was the Banana Pudding from Room service- it was so incredibly amazing! I had it twice during my stay- it's not too sweet- a smooth pudding base, ripe banana slices, whipped cream, then topped with Crumbled shortbread- I'm still craving it! I also loved the overall design, the carpet in the hallways leading to my room, the hip lobby, and the extremely good looking bellman! I had an amazing time and looking forward to returning soon. Thanks for an amazing stay! Best,Patrick Winkler

Loved our weekend at the Standard, High Line. I must say, almost everything about this chic hotel is great. Of course (everybody says it) the location in the meatpacking district and on the High Line absolutely is value-added to the experience. The staff at the front desk on our arrival was extremely nice (though the hostess' "cleavage" was a little distracting for this aging hipster I confess). Request a room in the higher floors for the views if possible, but I understand you don't want to be under the club on the top floors or right near the elevator. It was just a little too chilly to spend our first evening at the rooftop bar -- but the views from there were stunning. You just gotta go up there!I must say, the rooms do seem SMALL and a bit cramped, although well-designed. Bathrooms have HUGE tubs and super-comfy beds ==> the bed is too low to the floor for my taste & comfort. I guess this is a "design thing" because of the floor-to-ceiling windows. This is certainly not a hotel for fuds (I also stubbed my toe a few times on the mini step-up to the bathroom) -- and I certainly did not like getting turned away at the elegant upstairs bar first time around [for wearing sneakers not shoes]. Drinks at the bar were uber pricey -- but I suppose if you are paying the price of staying at this hotel, just be prepared to go with the flow! We had Saturday and Sunday breakfasts in the cozy bistro-café. Excellent breakfast food. For dinner I recommend Fig & Olive around the corner. Mini-bar was well stocked with plenty of alcohol and treats, but at a premium price (to be expected).Overall, we loved our stay -- and would likely return.

The location of the hotel above the high line trail, and in the meatpacking district was great. Lots of shopping and eating opportunities were available and we found we liked the neighborhood better than Soho. We stayed on the 7th floor in a Deluxe Queen ADA room with a view that faced the Hudson River, the Brass Monkey rooftop and the new Whitney, which is under construction. The room itself was comfortable. The ADA designation means that there is no bathtub, only a shower and the bathroom is large enough for a wheelchair to maneuver and has grab bars. The shower has one very dim light, so it might be difficult to see in there at night. Both the shower and bathroom are finished with shiny black-glazed tile.When you come into the room, the bathroom is on the left and shower on the right. The floor to ceiling windows are directly ahead with the bed area to the left and seating area and closet to the right. The seating area has a small sofa, table and leather swivel chair, a hanging fixture over the table and a magazine rack. The closet is behind a curtain and has two small cubbies a safe, a hanging rod with shelf above.The bed area has nightstands on either side of the bed and has a clock radio with iPod connector (old style). There are dimmable lights above the headboard and switch and dimmer for the room lights. The bath products in the room are pleasant, with a small glycerine soap bar, small pot of honey-scented body lotion, a packet of cotton balls/swabs and ear plugs. I brought my own ear plugs which blocked sound better than the ones provided. The shower has shampoo, conditioner and shower gel in pumps attached to the wall. The products had a nice Aveda-like scent but are not Aveda. The bed seemed spongy upon sitting on it, but for sleeping, it was very comfortable. Except for some loud-talkers in the hallway and the noise from the brass monkey, there wasn't much noise beyond the background din of the city. I use the earplugs to block out my partner's snoring!There is a mini bar in a fridge for beverages and a cabinet above for snacks. I couldn't find the price list anywhere in the room. There are wine glasses, an ice bucket, a wine opener in the room. There was a candle in the room but wasn't sure if this was a mini bar item or part of the amenities.The TV planted in the floor may have been a cool design idea (and perhaps helps with sound) but it interferes with getting out of one side of the bed and with the view. The heating/cooling worked well and didn't give us any problems.Facilities:The gym on the 17th floor is decent and has great views. There are about 6-8 cardio machines and maybe 2-4 weight machines. There are also some free weights. Not a lot of room for floor work, though.The open air rooftop bar and lounge is fun for a late afternoon/early evening drink. The upholstered furniture had nasty stains on it, so we stuck to the webbed chairs. The boom boom room has some marvelous views of the city and cozy spots to sit by a fireplace. If you want a drink here, you'll need to get it yourself. The staff only seem interested in serving certain tables. The plaza bar is good for people watching. Not all the seating has overhead heaters, so pay attention if you are sitting outside and want to be warm.The Standard Grill front room is a pleasant spot to have breakfast. Service is efficient and friendly. The servers wear funky plaid pants and vests. I suggest the hotel re-work the continental breakfast from the 1 hot (coffee/tea), 1 cold bev (orange/grapefruit juice), choice of pastries and choice of toast to work in some protein and fruit. Who needs pastries AND toast? Plus there are enough pastries in one person's order to feed two people. Continental breakfast was included in our room package,Getting up to the club late at night is impossible without an invitation or guest list privileges. We didn't inquire with the concierge about getting in ahead of time, so maybe that is how it works.They separate the guest elevators from the club elevators at night so we didn't experience the mix-up of club-goers and hotel guests I've read on other reviews.

Whilst location, design and the restaurants and bars are fantastic, it is once again the superb staff who made the 7 night stay outstanding. Nothing is too difficult for these guys!Looking forward to my next NYC visit.

We had a Queen size Deluxe Room on the 17th Floor, facing Uptown towards the Empire State Building - what a view - especially so at night from the bedroom seeing the twinkling lights! The service was excellent throughout our stay of 5 days, from booking in to drinking in the 18th floor Bar. The Standard Grill downstairs was one of the best meals - you just have to have the burger and share the huge brownie. A great stay we hope to return.

No matter what LA folks tell you, this location is the true "standard" for The Standard hotels. It's location in the heart of the Meatpacking District / West Village area along with its classy grill and beer garden make this the top choice for out-of-towners looking to have a few nights out in the city. The hotel clientele is young and international, much the same as the James Hotel. The two clubs at the roof level are both excellent, but for different reasons: The "Boom Boom Room" is great for casual cocktails as the sun sets on the city, and "Le Bain" is fun if you're looking for a late night spot to drink and dance until sunrise. This will always be on the short list of city destinations for a night out or a weekend stay.

+ Location, easy to dodge the worst trafic and walk to the best areas of NYC+ Stylish and modern+ Biergarten, Standard Grill and the *Living Room*, good food overall.+ Coctail bar on the roof top+ Very clean rooms.- Bad service- Snotty Employees (Except the waiter Creighton at the Standard Grill who was awsome)- Bad value for the money compared to other hotels in the area.- Be sure to pay extra to get a room with a view over the Hudson, cause the noise on the other side of the hotel will keep you up all night.- The harley bar next to the standard makes A LOT of noise during night time.- Amenities in the room did not work at all or worked sometimes.- Very poor wifi internet connection. A skype call is almost impossible to do.

Check in was smooth, although my wife felt all the receptionists showed too much cleavage with ill fitting bras. Once in the room the floor to ceiling window provides an undeniably amazing view. We had an Empire State facing window and slept with the curtains open both nights - falling asleep and waking up looking at the skyline was unbelievable. The concept of the shower having only a clear glass screen into the room was excellent.We were very disappointed not to be able to experience the bars. Largely due to having other commitments in the evening. But there was no possibility to add on to a late night guest list. My wife works in this industry in the UK and felt it was entirely due to leaving the decision of who enters to the bouncer (one receptionist did admit, the door staff make final decision) We were very embarrassed for some of our friends (also staying at the hotel) as we feel they were discriminated against.You are definitely paying for the view and the opportunity to make the most of the floor to ceiling windows!

I booked my short stay (of one night), for my girlfriends birthday. I knew little about the hotel other then it apparently had amazing views!Day of checking in: The lobby is tight and during checkin on the weekend it becomes FULL of people trying to get to their rooms or just people trying to get to the club upstairs or use the restrooms (because of the restaurant on the first floor). The woman who checked me in was very nice but must have forgotten to pull her shirt up because her cleavage was spewing out of her bra and shirt. Maybe its a New York thing?... Anyway, after waiting for an elevator to be open, I finally made it to my room. But, not so fast now..... my key didn't work. So I had to go all the way down to the front desk to ask for another. NOT so easy, it took me 20-25 minutes. They only had one set of elevators for drunk party goers and guests!!!!Room at first glance: OMG the shower is in see through. Maybe it was a little bit of my own fault but I didn't know all the showers where totally exposed. I am a semi private conservative normal person, and i don't want anyone who is staying with me being able to watch me shower... kinda awkward. THANKFULLY i was not traveling with anyone! The room did have a beautiful floor to ceiling window that was probably the length of my arms time two. It was neat and tidy. The bathroom shower had beautiful tiles. Hopefully if I was staying with someone they would be so memorized by it they wouldn't be looking at me trying to shower.Checking out:This was a nightmare in a half. I had them valet my car but no one told me they were closing the street down for a parade. So I had to wait hours to get my car, along with a slew of angry travelers. Rightfully so because some were missing flights and what not. Please if management is reading this, please do not contact me again about my review. Thank you!

The truth is that the target market The Standard High Line is aimed at (style-conscious, pre-family, free-spenders) can't really afford its punchy prices, unless they're on expense accounts with the nearby fashion stores. So there's plenty of scope for the meeter/greeters to not-quite-engage with those wheeling cases through the yellow revolving doors, but . . . none of this can take away from The Standard being a fantastic hotel experience. Amazing rooms (admittedly compact), with amazing views (east across the city and west across the Hudson), a great location in the Meatpacking District, and fantastic eating/drinking options (The Standard Grill, Biergarten, The Room, 18th floor cocktail bar, and some mythical 19th floor thing that we couldn't get access to) without having to go onto the street. Highly recommended despite the difficulties of top-floor access. Why would you want to stay anywhere else in New York?

A great visit in a busy night in the city.The staff was terrific and fast, and checking was smooth. Good time to stay as the hotel was partially full but the roof bar was closed due to a private party. Will definitely come back!Check out the beer garden next door!!

Arrived early and were able to check in at noon. This almost never happens in NYC.Had brunch on the terrace. Food and service was very good.Room was small but we knew that. Floor to ceiling windows with a fantastic view of the Manhattan skyline! Our room had a direct view of the Empire State Building.The meat packing district is a very cool section of the city right next to the village.Shopping was awesome with outstanding resturants within walking distance.The roof top night club is hot! Dress accordingly.During the day the roof top is a very cool place to hand out for a drink and small bits.Sunset Views are as good as any in the city!Had lunch outside. this was a different menu than the terrace dining. Food and service was excellent!

My family and I have stayed at The Standard High Line twice now, even though we actually live down the road! Both times we needed a "staycation" and on both occasions we found it to be a lovely experience. The rooms are beautifully designed and the view is incredible from any floor. I always try to stay at an Andre Balazs hotel if there is one in town because I know the service and design is going to be great. The Standard was no exception and we were particularly impressed with Joseph Tighe on the front desk as he took care of us so well during both our stays, making sure everything was perfect. Highly recommend this hotel to anyone.

I've stayed at The Standard 3 times so far as a staycation for my boyfriend and I. We both lead busy lives in NYC and need to get away sometimes...and The Standard provides a sexy, fun escape from the norm. I booked the Hudson Studio this time for my boyfriend's birthday because I wanted an extra special experience. I was floored by the 3 walls of windows and the clean, contemporary decor. Watching the sunset over the Hudson was priceless.The staff was super friendly and accommodating. The woman who checked us in was warm and welcoming...and they jumped up to help me find a cab in the morning at 6am to get to work. They even sent us a complimentary bottle of champagne and some fruit to make sure our experience was special. They even checked in on me after my stay to make sure I was satisfied with my stay. The level of warmness and care provided by the staff is rare to find these days...especially in NYC!!! I would definitely recommend this hotel to anyone looking to treat themselves to an elegant, alluring night in the city!
user_location: New York, New York, United States

review_body: Reading many reviews on here...i was slightly daunted by my upcoming stay at The Standard but thankfully the entire experience was good for us! I travelled with my husband for his birthday, I emailed beforehand to ask about special touches I could put in the room for arrival and was promptly sent a list of items I could pre-pay for & the restaurant also contacted me right away to ask if I wanted to make Fri/Sat night reservations. Good service! On arrival, we were warmly greeted by door staff and again at reception (I need to know where those reception ladies get their bras!!) lobby was stylish, buzzing, and checkin was prompt. Bags were escorted with us to our amazing room...we were both blown away by the view!! We booked a superior king room with empire view. The porter / door staff both brought our cases & showed us all of the room amenities which was nice. The bed was comfy, room an ok size for NYC, shower amazing (we are newlyweds so a see-through shower was fine!!) very well stocked minibar and welcome blackout curtains to make sure we got a decent sleep through sunrise.We arrived back to our room after a meal later that night to a lovely complimentary bottle of prosecco and a happy birthday note from the management! Very nice :-)We had heard issues with the rooftop bars so we decided to avoid to make sure we left The Standard on a high. We ate breakfast in the Grill one morning & found the food and service great - only issue is tables very very close together! We never once experienced issues with elevator queues & we stayed Thurs - Sun.Tips: We ate at local restaurant The Spice Market and it was lovely!! Also The Diner is great for breakfast & the highline is a lovely walk.Enjoy x

I love this place. I love the rooms, they are clean, beautifully and intelligently styled, the views are magical, location is wonderful, food is just as good as a hotel food service should be. Prices are okay, and cheaper in the office season. But the service just [anger word] sucks! Again and again and again the service sucked on a two day trip.- greeters / maitres-d: why are these people so digustingly sour? seriously who do they think they are. When you want a table they look at you like you are disrupting their spa therapy, what total idiocy. Just give me a freaking table and stop acting like a fool. - breakfast: had to ask three times for milk, twice reminded orange juice order, no spoon for tea, two servers not-coordinating, just annoying.- reception: almost always empty, and never welcoming. so pathetic. six terminals and usually no more than two people on service. At one point, I stood looking in horror at a reception that for a some horrifying minutes had not a single soul at front of house. I don't remember a hotel in the world where there was no-one at reception. - terrace bar: again, no-one giving me a table, no-one noticing I wanted to order when I had a table, and then when a party of 5 grew to 8, being told we couldn't expand the table (fire regs? what rubbish, there was no clear access already, and we could have arranged tables to ensure it). - elevators: this BS makes me want to scream. what is going on with all these non-hotel guests crashing the elevators in the evening? when you come back tired, wanting to get to your room, you have to navigate all that horror. stop it immediately. And the staff, using the guest elevators for luggage, waste, housecleaning, whatever. This is a clownshow. Get it sorted. AND ENOUGH WITH THE BROKEN ELEVATORS. - guest priority: when I wake up on Sunday in your hotel I want breakfast. Is that some kind of surprise? so why do I have to wait in a huge queue of non-hotel guests for the privilege of eating in my own hotel, not to mention navigating the wall of sour that the greeters desk represents. And please, I've read your replies here. You sound like you listen, but never offer to actually look into anything. Try and fix this stuff. Its the second time I stayed, and the problems are the same. Please fix, or it's one more try then I'm out. Thanks.

My wife and I have stayed at The Standard twice, once in the (pricey) Empire Suite, which we used for an after party following our 25th anniversary. This is a modern, well appointed space with great rooms and the Meat Packing district is becoming quite (if not too) fashionable. If you haven't walked the High Line (an abandoned rail line turned into an elevated park) this is highly recommended (despite a few cranky detractors) and it is free! The bar at the top of the hotel is gorgeous but turns into a private club late (it would be nice for hotel guests to have access but I guess we are not (too) fashionable enough. Both times upon check in I found the hotel staff to be a bit condescending, I don't think a smile or a polite "yes sir" would do them any harm. There is valet parking which is great at checking in but you want your vehicle you'd better give them thirty minutes notice because I think they garage the cars in Queens (I'm not kidding). All in all this is a great base of operations for a stay in Manhattan especially for pleasure seekers or sight seers.

My husband and I stayed for a one night "staycation" in our own city and had a great time. Service is great - everyone was very friendly and welcoming, and they kindly gave us a free upgrade to a nicer room (booked via Jetsetter). The views and room decor are fantastic - I want my apartment to look like that room. The room was much quieter than I would have expected, which was especially appreciated after hours when the neighborhood gets a bit obnoxious. Not the best hotel bed I've ever experienced, but fine for a night or two. Good coffee and people watching during a relaxing breakfast at patio restaurant in the morning. It's expensive, but the details and experience are worth the splurge (and there are very often deals to be found ....).

Good things:- Perfect location, super close to a very hip area full of clubs, restaurants, shopping, Chelsea Market...- Beautifully designed big room (I had the corner room)- Concierge and staff were great- Rooftop is gorgeous, especially on a sunny afternoonCould be better:- no curtains for the showers... so zero privacy if staying with a partner, and water splashes everywhere!

This hotel is really cool. It kinda straddles the High Line, and has a nice outside beer garden that has steps up to the High Line. Rooms are great - very cool - although very low bed so ideal for those of us that like to fall out in the morning. Upstairs bar is really cool with great New York acts performing. Staff are excellent. This is on my list for trips to NY.

When I pay $735 as a nightly rate I have high expectations. We stayed at the hotel for three nights in a Empire King Corner room 1010. The bed was comfortable; however the room is starting to show its age. The carpet was worn and the small couch / lounge chair was useless accept for shopping bags and as place for your clothes. The room DOES not have any place unpack your belonging accept for a very SMALL open closet with a drape. Trendy and chic I think not. The bathroom tile from circa 1970 should be rethought. It is quite an eyesore. Thankfully the bed was super comfortable. The view was fantastic. Our greeting by the bell staff was exceptionally friendly and our check-in process went very smoothly. Now lets talk about this hotels MAJOR FLAW.... Guests should not be made to grovel, beg or wine to gain access to a roof top that is advertised on its website. In fact, the website should be updated to reflect the extremely limited and almost non-existance access for hotel guests. Our first night on the roof top was fantastic. Unfortunately all of the other nights were supposedly guest list only. I thought this had to be a joke since it once of the prominent selling features of the property on the website. After speaking with management we were assured this would not be an issue the third night of our stay. To our dismay, yes the less than friendly door staff used the guest list line again! The manager of the property apologized and comped our party its entire drink bill at The Grill. FYI, this is a great place to eat! The service, food and ambiance is awesome! We ate here twice during our stay. Again, at this price point guest should be given priority access and or guest list access to the rood OR DISCLOSE it on the website otherwise that you may or MAY NOT be able to enjoy the roof top. I hope the management team wakes up or they are going to have a lot of unhappy guests find a new trendy hotel to stay!

Andre Balazs Knows how to create a great experience in his hotels. We still miss him here in Miami Beach at the Raleigh Hotel. Wish he would buy it back.The Standard HIgh Line hotel was really great, Magnificent views from our rooms in the upper floors. Great services, great food and friendly staff. My only not so good observation was the access the hotel guests have to go to the rooftop parties. (Way too much attitude even for NYC nowdays). They need to tone it down big time.We were there 4 nights and only one night was great (the first night on Friday). Easy access the first night- great vibe, music etc. They the following nights we had to go to the roof top of the Gansevort Hotel to enjoy the sunset. Well we had fun and spent lots of money there. We will be back and stay at the Standard- however- the roof top-... humm.... we will see.

For New Year, a friend and I decided to treat ourselves to a night at The Standard. Standing astride the Highline, the hotel is perfectly positioned for visit to New York in that part of town. The bar is simply fabulous, although it closes early. The rooms are tight and I'm not sure about the glass wall between the shower and the room but the views are spectacular.

When I can book at a not insane price, the is my favorite place to stay. I am totally NOT interested in the social scene downstairs, or upstairs—both of which can be full of attitude from both the staff and the clientele. I'm always there on business, so want a good place to shut down. I love the windows and the views. It's so nice to come back from a long day of meetings and work, turn off all the lights and open all the curtains, letting the ambient light of NYC fill the room. So soothing. Food is great - both in-house and in the neighborhood. Being on top of the High Line is a bonus for long walks in decent weather.

I stayed 4 nights at The Standard on the High Line in NYC. I was really pleased by the location of the hotel in a nice trendy district, with a stunning view and an easy access to the High Line which is an amazing place! My room (deluxe King) was really nicely designed, big enough and really comfortable. The food was great and the staff was quite cheerful and was carrying properly about my needs. It was good value for money and I will definitely recommend it to my friends!

Stayed here in September 2013. We're a 50+ semi retired couple and have been to NY a couple of times before and we're looking for a different experience. The reviews of the Standard sounded great so we jumped in. Our first concern was the reported noise from the roof top night club so we took the advice received on this site and asked for a room on the 9th to 11th floors and received one, through a special request, on the 10th floor. This was an excellent outcome as we heard no noise from above during the week we were there, including Friday and Saturday nights.The room was good - a good size for NY and, as we upgraded, we had a fantastic view of lower Manhattan and the Hudson River. Great morning and night time views from the wall of glass in the room. Don't be put off by the comments in other reviews as, in our room at least, we had real curtains that we could pull across for privacy, but we enjoyed leaving the curtains open as we turned in to see the skyline and lights down Washington St each night.We did go up to the roof top lounge one night and enjoyed the fantastic skyline views but avoided the nightclub - just too old for that but were amused each night as we saw the constant stream of young and beautiful people coming and going. Even as we left on our last day at 4:30 am to catch an early flight we were amazed at the activity in the hotel!Service was unpredictable and we were a little disappointed in the occasional careless attitude we experienced. Having said that, we were totally impressed with the service received from a young concierge, Tim, who arranged 4 dinner bookings for us, including at the popular Locande Verde. Thanks, Tim. The concierge also arranged a car to take us to the airport which was ideal at the early hour we had to leave.On the down side, we had to ask for more soap and the cleaning staff knocked on our door at about 9 am until we decided to put out the Do Not Disturb sign to allow us to have a good sleep before heading out to discover the delights of lower Manhattan.The hotel is located over the High Line and is in the very popular Meatpacking District. We loved it there and enjoyed walking through Chelsea, SoHo, Little Italy etc each day. The shopping, cafés and restaurants in these areas are nothing less than excellent. We had so much fun just walking around each day and then dining out at some of the best restaurants we've been to.The room wasn't inexpensive but it was worth the money for the experience. Go there, if only just once to see for yourself!

We spent the last night of our 2 week trip to New York at the Standard Highline and the highlights were the amazing view from our rooms and the comfortable beds. We had to book 2 rooms as there was no way an extra bed would fit in any of the rooms, not even the suites. The standard room was aptly described as a "capsule" by another TripAdvisor reviewer. My husband and I stayed in a corner suite which was only slightly larger but considerably more expensive. We were very disappointed with the service often spending half an hour before someone took our order and another half an hour trying to track someone down to sign for the bill. The service in the restaurant (The Standard Bar and Grill) was appalling with the waiter forgetting our requests and leaving us unattended for lengthy periods. The roof top bar is a great place to view the lights of Manhattan but after 11pm the hotel lift will not take you up there and we had to line up outside to gain entry to the lift. I will not stay at this hotel again and would not recommend it as I think it is overpriced for the experience.

I was really looking forward to our trip to the highline. I was a little nervous because of the mixed reviews. However, I really enjoyed the hotel. We were in a Hudson Studio with views in three different direction: uptown, downtown and the Hudson. We could see the Statute of Liberty, the Freedom Tower, and the Empire State building. Just amazing. I think some of the reviewers with negative comments go to the Highline with the wrong expectations. It is not a luxurious, cushy hotel. It has a different vibe. Its styling is more modern and trendy but that is okay and the décor reflects this modern and minimalist style. We found the staff to be great, from the valet parkers, to the beautiful and friendly receptionist and to the restaurant staff at the Standard Grill. Room service for breakfast was fast and friendly. We did not have a problem getting into Le Bain, even though we were older than the typical patron. Although it wasn't as wild and crazy as I thought it would be. They should, as other reviewers said, allow hotel guest easier access to the roof top bars. You can get there but you have to go outside and line up on 13th street. That's weird. Same thing trying to get back to your room from the club at night. You have to go down outside and then go through the lobby. I guess they need to control access to the guest room floors but it is still a pain. Of course the location in the meat packing district is great. Lots of shops, restaurants and places to visit and not too far from midtown or Soho.There are a couple of criticisms that I have. The main counter/console in the room had wood veneer trim which was splitting and delaminating. They need to spend a little money on the furniture to keep it fresh. I also thought it was odd that the floor in the front dining room of the Standard Grill seemed pretty dirty. Maybe it is stained but it just doesn't look good at all. Clean or replace the floor.Overall lots of fun.

Style here rates way too highly over substance. This Standard is geared more as a night club than a hotel. Even then, unless you intend to spend your time queuing, vogueing, being ignored by staff and partying in equal measure forget it. Guests rate last. Sleep, just above that. The receptionist told a guest checking in to an upper floor that it may be an issue if they were "sensitive to noise": good advice! Those with ears are better served elsewhere. We were on a slightly lower floor and I needed my noise cancelling earbuds for sleeping. On Saturday night, even they were beaten. The top floor bar is spectacular, although near impossible to access. Once inside, the glamorous wait staff will snub you unless they know you or you are more glamorous than them: the room was spoiled by the people in it. The Biergarten had a line which snaked around the corner. On the plus side the concierge staff were pleasant and helpful and the bikes were great if you got one. On check out, I queried a mini bar charge and was told there was no option but to charge it. When I asked about my promised F&B credit, I was told that could not be done although to compensate the receptionist gained the ability to revoke the minibar tab. This confirmed my view that the staff are trained to say no over yes, although they do look good doing it.
